Life of a manager (nanny):

Your solid/important player wants to go to bigger leagues/teams, throws hissy fit if I don't sell them for pennies, eventually get enough money from them to sell and found good/better replacement. Smile while you watch them to waste their next 4-5 years in reserve team bench. While you roll on the millions you got from him.

Your just recently signed fringe/impact sub comes 15-20 games in season to ask new contract, because he thinks he's so important to team and wants star money with his 2 starts and 1 assist in those 15-20 games. Say no, watch him throw hissy fit and screams how he's going to ruin my career. Rest of the team doesn't gaf about him, because they love me because I always pet their heads when they train properly. Eventually gets loaned/sold to team in some siberian farm league. 

Alternative version of earlier, you actually give the guy raise because figure that he's okay for the future. Again beginning of next season comes to ask more money again, just because. Sell him instantly away to some league with smaller salaries and smile while he wastes his next couple years there with less money.

Hold team meeting just before cup/league finals, tell the guys play well and become champions. Everyone is thrilled/encouraged. Except 2-3 guys who spent whole season as fringe/emergency backups, which throw hissy fit for too big ambitions. Win championship/cup, sell the complainers next summer to some beer league teams for pennies. Smile as they probably never reach that stage again.


Also always remember to pet your players gently and praise them if they're doing well in training or matches, if you don't they don't like you as nann..manager. Also if they're doing poorly you always have to tell them that's bad, or they don't like you as manager.


10/10 would nanny again.

What more needs to be said? I came into this with a rudimentary understanding of football and now I'm a self-confessed addict. 
What is essentially a series of numbers interacting with each other (more so than any other game) produces such high-stakes drama that I've elicited concern from housemates at my explosive swearing or cheering. Your attachment to your team and players, and subsequent exploration of their real-life counterparts, results in a grand soap opera experience where losing can be just as thrilling as victory. I now have an encyclopaedic knowledge of Colombian football and it's byzantine league system for instance! 
While there is an inexhaustible supply of resources online to help in tactic formation and player selection, Football Manager still remains opaque enough that my main concerns are likely conspiracy theories. 
I feel like team training is way over-thought by most guides (it's just raising the bars using the appropriate training module right?). I'm also CONVINCED that there's a dice-roll whenever you start the game which determines whether you inexplicably drop in form! 
This is my first foray into the franchise, which has long been criticised for resting on it's laurels and iterating slowly. Should this be my only Football Manager though, the experiences and dramas will be more than enough to get my money's worth. 
Also: f*** you PSG!
its a football fans dream job

The manager of Southampton squatted on the touchline, eerily reminiscent of the great Marcelo Bielsa that famously won the quadruple with Barnet F.C in 2035, watching his golden generation battle it out with the title favourites, Grimsby Town.

With Kyle Walker-Peters being the only footballer over 30 in his team, the manager decided that his golden generation of "regens" (lovingly referred to by the media) would go on to compete for decades to come, adorning the Southampton trophy cabinet with vast riches and treasure.

The 4-2-3-1 gegenpress was as familiar a sight as the smell of hotdogs and burgers as the fans edged closer to the stadium on a match day.

Drawing 1-1 in the 88th minute, the manager of Southampton decided to switch from the 10 minute spam, as if by clockwork, of "Demand more" to "Berate" and, like a bolt of lightning had erupted from the drab, winter's sky, the Southampton side kicked into gear with aplomb in the form of a key highlight.

Unfortunately for Southampton, things did not go to plan. Kyle Walker-Peters' run, while astute and profound, found the feet of Julian Alvares who, now his mid 30s, shot the ball straight at the wonderkid goalkeeper from Brazil, who happened to already be capped with the senior international team - a man known for possessing reflexes to match even the most acrobatic of felines.

With a long goal kick out, the Grimsby Town players ran for the ball like they had never ran before. Grimsby's young Spanish inverted-winger played a floated cross into the box from the right and, to the relief of the hot-dog eating Southampton faithful, had not troubled their young, Croatian wonderkid goalkeeper. However, this was not the end of the highlight.

In a frantic attempt to counter the counter, the ball was kicked straight up into the air - or so the goalkeeper had wished for. Instead, the ball was kicked straight into the posterior of Kyle Walker-Peters and slowly but surely made its way over the Southampton goal line. On this rare occasion, VAR was not consulted, and the Southampton players held their heads in their hands, knowing that another defeat to the almighty Grimsby FC was on the cards this season, and their hopes at challenging for the title were in tatters.


In conclusion, if you're looking for a great football game generator set in a period of wonderkids and wage problems, this is the game for you. 

You can figure out for yourself if you like the graphics and audio or not, I have no problems with either. If you won't be playing 4-2-3-1 gegenpress, be prepared for a less fun time (and if you don't "wire the world" when scouting as a certain YouTuber says, are you really playing?).

Plus, the AI loves to set enormous asking prices for the best wonderkids, so be prepared to pay for the editor as well so you can transfer them to your club for free. Don't worry, you'll build a team full of wonderkids that conquers the footballing world in no time...you did remember to buy players with only 15+ determination that aren't fickle, right?

i played FM since 2004 and still best managerial games i ever know, much improvement and still love it.

>Pull off a shocking upset 3-0 FA Cup with a non league team in 3rd round.
>Other manager shit talking in leadup to match.
>Responded and escalated it with more heat.
>Bludgeon their squad.
>Postmatch he whines saying they were better team it was an anomoly and it wont happen next time.
>14 journalists show up for post match.
>2 questions not related. 
>Conference ends.
FM puts effort into shit like "Social Feed" and any immersion in the game continues to be worse than FM had almost a decade ago when you could legit call up a journalist to trash talk and start drama with other managers.

Other Examples of dreadful game engine/game mechanics: 
1) The amount of blocked shots (and never have I once seen a handball called) the AI gets in FM21 would be world record setting.... and I usually start files in English tier 6 with....much better players. 

2) Scouting I would argue is worse (explicitly give instructions you want no players under x age, scouts give you scouting reports on 38 year olds anyways, wasting time that could scout young talent), and contract negotiations are laughable. 

3) AI staff/players are mindbogglingly stupid in their contract decisions refusing to even entertain discussions with clubs with a max rating "Friend/Idol" Manager because of club "stature" where in the past, recruiting people who respect you was a given, and a scrub tier young players insisting they want to be starters.

So...If not for the streamlined training system added a few years ago, I wouldn't hesitate to play FM15 instead. Sadly my old editor data never got backed up so I'm stuck with it.

 I expect 22 to be just as garbage. SI, like most devs these days, seems to not actually play their own games. If FIFA actually had English clubs below League 2 (Tier 4) and all it's domestic cups, so I could play with lower clubs, I'd drop FM immediately.

Also, go figure, none of these issues were addressed, and according to some reviews got worse, including fullbacks not marking. I recommend grabbing any FM prior to 2018 you can get your hands on, FM13 or FM15 ideally. If I hadn't lost my awesome FM15 editor files I made myself I'd be playing that right now instead.

Always loved Football Manager overall, have been playing this and the previous incarnation for 20+ years.

But the match rigging element (which has always existed) seems a bit too rigid this edition. I know the purists have always argued "Oh matches aren't rigged" and mostly they're not. Skill of the player is key. But you get the odd game that is simply unwinnable.

For example, I'm currently playing a game purely for my own amusement where my focus is on the second season of Real Madrid having won everything in the first season. So I'm cheating and re-loading defeats to create that scenario I want. Not claiming it's not cheating. 10 games into season I'm winning most games because it;s Real Madrid. You expect that. The odd defeat I can live with as long as (for my own scenario) it's not crucial.

Just played Cadiz. They're bottom of La Liga. Lost every game. Scored three goals in total. They also have injury problems with not a single recognised striker. I'm largely full strength and no fitness issues.

I know the game is SUPPOSED to do calculations based on player quality, strategy vs strategy, factor in form, fitness and player morale etc. Then it should add a small factor of luck. That decides the outcome. I accept on rare occasions, Cadiz win this game out of nowhere. 

I have played that fixture, lost, reloaded it and played it again TWENTY-SEVEN times. And lost every time. EVERY SINGLE GAME, I mean every single one, Madrid miss a penalty. Every single game Madrid has huge numbers of attempts to their almost nothing. Every single game, Luka Modric is booked in the first 10 mins and they always win by one goal, every single time. Never scoring more that 2. I've counted them up, 27 games has produced 49 disallowed goals.

The game has decided that I lose this match, like it or not, nothing I can do about it. No formation, so strategy, no line up no turn of events sees me win this.

Like i said, I'm cheating, that's how I'm seeing this. Normally you move on, take the hit and never know.

I object to games being unwinnable.

I'll start off with the negatives: It is boring at first. Very boring. If you aren't the type to commit to games and go a couple hours without particularly enjoying yourself then this game isn't for you. Secondly, it is very much 'easy to learn, hard to master.' I have played this game a lot and still haven't mastered it, as it takes a lot of dedication in terms of time to master it. Really you should be spending more time looking at the finer details of the game as you play, but I don't bother and neither do everyone I know who play FM. Lastly, and perhaps most frustratingly, this game crashes tons. I hear it's not only me, a lot of people have had this problem and I simply can't stand it. 


In terms of positives, there are a lot of good aspects to this game: Firstly, it feels very realistic. Relationships with other managers, data, x.g, youth development and more all contribute to this feel. Secondly, the diversity and selection. You can choose to play this game pretty much in any way you'd like. Choose to manage from most teams that exist and your save could go on forever without stopping movement around the world, there are no limits. Long term saves are particularly satisfying as you can pretty much say 'Huh, I remember seeing this guy come through as a 15 year old exciting prospect, and now he's the best player in my team', this is very oddly satisfying. In a way, this game has also taught me a lot about real life football. Tactics and positions I had never known before, and players and nations I didn't know were alright at football. 

In summary, this game is incredibly fun for most people that are interested in football on a level that isn't just playing it. It is very realistic, satisfying and detailed but crashes more often than not. I believe for the right person it is definitely worth the price.

Best FM Game I've played to date. Match Engine is better than ever. The new UI is everything I could've asked for (with the exception of not being able to see live scores), and the overhauls to press conferences, match analysis have given the game a very fresh feel. FM20 feels like a distant memory, and retrospectivley, a much shittier entry than I first realized. FM21 solves every problem or issue I had with FM20 (the big one being the match engine that eliminated one on ones). 

Now I will say this. I've read a lot of negative reviews about this game, in which the reviewer described the game as being all luck based or whatever. To that I say, I can't be the judge, as I only started purchasing FM games in 2019.  But I will say this. Re-releasing the same game over and over again with new features every year is only gonna work until a point. The only reason I got FM21 was because the FM20 match engine was annoying the crap out of me. But now that I have FM21 and its so much better, and is everything I want in an FM game, I have no reason to buy FM22 (I still might, but I don't see why I should now). 

So I recommend to people to just, get mods for the current season and hunker down on your favourite version of FM instead of paying for a new game that constantly updates every year. For me, the FM game I want to hunker down currently with is FM21

TL;DR: Bad. Bad. Bad. Crashy, buggy mess. They believe they "don't need to release info about new games because our fans should buy our new titles no matter what." That's the company that you are supporting. SI is a prime example of capitalism without competition. The founder, Miles, is an absolute insufferable prick to top it all off.

EDIT: Edited after playing thru a couple more seasons with a lot more playtime. This game is... not good, guys. I'm sorry. Seriously, how this company manages to ruin key components every single edition such as player interactions is honestly impressive. Guess what, y'all, it actually ISN'T fun playing babysitter with completely mentally-braindead player AI on your team! 

"COACH, YOU DIDN'T EVEN REGISTER ME FOR THE LEAGUE! I WANT A TRANSFER IMMEDIATELY." - League registration window is more than 45 days away. Btw, I selected "auto select players to register" and had an additional EIGHT OPEN PLACES IN MY SQUAD. THANKFULLY, GREAT AI DIDN'T WANT TO INCLUDE THIS PLAYER IN MY TEAM FOR NO REASON SO NOW HE IS MAD!

Here's another favorite: I offer a player for sale. "COACH, WHY ARE YOU TRYING TO SELL ME? THIS IS PISSING ME OFF. I NO LONGER TRUST YOU AND I DEMAND A TRANSFER." LMAO! Amazing, incredible updates. Seriously SI, you ought to just be embarrassed. Add on top of this Miles' (lead developer) incredibly blase attitude towards any suggestions that he doesn't agree with. This game is headed straight for the dumpster as soon as any competent competitor comes along.

Tactics are clearly more cookie-cutter than ever, xG has the be THE most frustrating addition to the game I've ever seen (if you thought watching your team lose with 40 shots to 2 was frustrating, wait until you lose with an xG of 6 to an xG of 0.1!), and the FIFA-level "scripted" feeling is so apparent it's almost insulting. 

I cannot support this company anymore. I have purchased every edition since FM 2010. They copy-paste virtually the EXACT same game with updated rosters every year (which, by the way, are horribly updated - Man United for example has been massively overrated for at least a decade). Sports Interactive has to be the shining example of why competition is so crucially important in business. With no competition whatsoever, they feel completely justified in rehashing the same sub-par product from 20 years ago. They created an unbelievable, genre-defining game with the Championship Manager series. Unfortunately, I think FM is going to go the way of Call of Duty - straight into the garbage bin.

I will not be purchasing FM in the future. Enough is enough.



I don't normally write reviews, but I left a blasting review of FM 20 - so it only seems fair that I'd recommend this one.

Even though they (imo) completely butchered the new UIs and things like xG are totally worthless additions, the vast improvements to the match engine in this edition represent actual, noticeable steps forward that you'd expect of a "new game" instead of bulls&%t fluff changes that they normally do with roster updates for each new edition. As long as they make actual technical advancement to the game, like they have in this version with the match engine, I will gladly overlook whatever other minor additions they decide to add as these are not important to the game's actual quality.

So, have fun with your random "feature" additions and do them however you want - much of this is moddable anyway. However, it's nigh impossible to mod the match engine, transfer AI, etc. Hope you continue this good work of upgrading the game technically, SI!

[H1]THE SHORT OF IT: THE GREAT LEAP FORWARD[/H1]

FM21 is a fantastic evolution to the series, and hits the spot for soccer professionals like me as we build up our IRL careers into something bigger and better.

[H1]WHAT'S NEW?[/H1]

With the full release of FM22 less than a month away,  it's prime time for reflecting on what FM21 brought to the series and what we as players are hoping to see in FM22. When people reflect on FM21, I think they'll remember the improved match day feel and streamlined system, making you feel as if you're in control of every aspect of your team. In fact, FM21 cleared up a lot of the issues I had with the series for multiple years in terms of clunkiness and randomness. 

I hope that FM22 (and based on the things that have been announced e.g. the new deadline day system, more options for stat geek-level analysis etc it seems like it will) focuses more on polishing the gem that was FM21 rather than trying to re-invent the wheel and getting stuck in the mud.

[H1]FINAL SCORE:[/H1]

****3/4 out of five (excellent value at any price for people who might even be vaguely interested in the genre)

I love getting lost in this game! All the aspects of football that I adore and then some however it is not without its faults. I have only played two FMs so far this one and 20. I plan on getting 22 when it comes out, but for the time being I felt compelled to talk about what I thought about this installment.  I am about 35 years into a save moving from the USA with Austin FC to having an illustrious career at Borussia Mönchengladbach enjoying every bit of it.
The match engine has greatly improved with being able to score many different types of goals and not seeing my team become side-netting FC. Enjoy getting close to my players with the interactions, while tedious and repetitive it adds a nice element to it. I feel like press conferences, pre/post game interviews need a rework or something. Its incredibly boring and I feel adds nothing fun to the game. The tactics are always fun to mess around with to see what works, but I always feel like I am at a disadvantage whenever I don't use an attacking style of play no matter what. Also with the way formations work I always find myself coming back to the 4-3-2-1 Wide. As much I wanted to use different ones again I felt like the game doesn't offer much success with others. Plus the regens I would get in youth academies didn't offer much else in differing positions.
Either way I adore this game and find myself getting lost in it for hours on end. It can obviously be improved in many ways but in its current state it isn't too bad and provides a good way to enjoy the in depth side of football.

A definite improvement from the previous edition. Personally felt that FM20 a bit of a step back in the core tactical side of FM while adding new features in the miscellaneous management area. Thankfully, FM21 improves a lot on some of the weird tactical stuff in FM20 besides continuing the trend of adding little features make the managerial experience more realistic (asking agent about player availability, removal of the role suitability circle, a hell of a lot improved image scan for manager character...especially female faces, the dugout section instead of perpetual pop ups, etc).

I feel like they’re exploiting the loyalty of their customers. Every year they do the same thing. They leave a knowingly buggy game broken and then expect us all to pay for it again next year in hope that they’ve finally fixed what we paid for last year. Don't get me wrong, FM21 is still the greatest football management game ever made... But then again, is there really any worthy competition or any to compare it to? All we can do is compare it to last years which it is always going to be better than because its the same game with more content.

Off the pitch the experience is nearly perfect in terms of football simulation and management. While on the pitch the game has really a clumsy and obnoxious match engine. Those saying it has good graphics must be stuck in 2005 cos they're fking dreadful. Another issue is the lack of new interactions. Every question from the press is repetitive af, the same player interactions, random responses from players that you would not expect. You tell a player he had a good training session and he gets upset that you are happy with his training cos he thinks his training was not good enough. Ok mate. Then the argument drags out over months and he ends up sold in the next window. Stupid. Makes you not want to interact with players at all.

Overall, FM21 is a great game. You will spend countless hours perfecting your tactics, tweaking your player roles, finding the next best football player in the market, twiddling your finances, and much more. Off the pitch the game is amazing and won't disappoint. The fake 'social media' part of FM is great and I love reading it, but yet again like everything else... Its the same old things repeated again and again.

If you've never played FM or haven't played for a few years then you'll have an incredible time and it'll take up half your life. If you've played FM recently then there is hardly any new things and it isn't worth the price tag.

Observations: the depth of this game is vast compared to FIFA. With a couple hundred hours into it, I only made it to the end of my fourth season. Granted, it was my first time ever playing an FM game so it took me awhile to learn. I watched numerous YouTube videos, Twitch channels, you name it. I was all in. Now, I'm exhausted. I was told that the game was more realistic than FIFA, maybe so. But the actual games... infuriatingly unrealistic. 

The amount of times the opposition scored in the final moments of stoppage time, times the opposition scored multiple goals a man down, times my players played the ball directly to the other team leading to one-on-ones with the GK. (Memphis Depay notoriously did this two times in a single game and at least 5 times in a season before I rage sold him for pennies on the dollar to the Chinese Super League.) I get it, unpredictable things happen in soccer/futbol. Great. But not like this. Not to where these are the usual. Not to where you become so numb that you no longer have anxiety as the extended highlight shows the inevitable.

In their determination to make it unpredictable, they made the game unplayable.

My breaking point was a little experiment that I did with Liverpool and Chelsea. More specifically, Liverpool U23 and Chelsea. In the FA Cup Quarter Final. The game had made me so jaded towards Liverpool that I just wanted to destroy them. I pulled out the In-Game Editor for the first time and stuck it to Liverpool. I loaned out all their Senior squad members, making them play with only their U23 players. But that wasn't all. I wanted them to feel my anger, my hate, so I made all of them "Abysmal" morale through the editor as well. That would do the trick.

I was wrong.

After 7 games, Chelsea's senior squad starting eleven finally beat Liverpool U23 in the FA Cup Quarter Final.

The U23 squad won 3 games, tied another 3 and finally lost the final game.

Different formations were tried, 5-3-2, 5-2-1-2, 4-2-3-1, 4-3-3
Different starting styles: Defensive, Cautious, Balanced, Positive, Attacking. But all led to Very Attacking in the final 10 minutes trying to muster another goal in the waning minutes of stoppage time. Yet Klopp prevailed with his Youngsters time after time.

The final (only) win: 4-2-3-1, Gengenpress, Attacking. But even then, Klopp had his group of U23 tied 2-2 in the 80th minute before conceding two late goals to lose 4-2.

That was when the realism was lost. Regardless of tactics, formations, or style, Chelsea starting eleven should beat Liverpool U23 barring the use of extremely unrealistic formations.

I had started to question the realism in my first save when I was Manchester United and won the treble (Premier, FA, Champions)  in my first year (completely unrealistic) without ever save-scumming. The FM gods granted me this, trying to suck me in. And it worked.

Maybe I'll play again. I can't say that I won't. I might have a weak moment. But I'm FM will quickly show it's colors.

T&P's to all you brave souls who continue the ruthless grind, for you are better men/women than I.

Took a 2 year break from this POS franchise and jumped back in to check if it improved. 

Nope same POS they left us with 3 years ago. Wing backs and wings still dribble to the touchline and shoot from a 1 degree angle regardless of instruction or training or really, anything but an act of god that they should drag a cross back to the 6. Pressing is completely useless via the lack of AI which is actually understandable but its painful to watch 2 of your players chase a guy or the ball around the field and not control the space. Computer generated Players and tactics rarely if ever can emulate the actual design of soccer/football which is the use and manipulation of actual space. So often players collide in the same space from the same team or block a teammates shot simply because they can't understand the fundamental guidelines of moving through and into space as it applies to football. The end result is something like my sons 8U Saturday AM games I coach. Fortunately I don't swear nearly as much at them as I do at the FM franchise because I expect it from them. And for those of you who think i've missed the mark because this is a manager franchise - I can't even get my wing backs to not take long throws to absolutely no one when I've ordered them to keep possession. so uhh.....yeah Nothing to see here move along

edit: 8/21 - bored AF and went back to remind myself why I don't ever play this - Yep still sucks. Absolute garbage. The transfer market is such a joke. Pennies on the dollar for my players, 386 million for Trent Alex-Arno.  even after i made him my #1 for a year and did all the right media things. Can ONLY retain players with huge contracts. That's not a new fucking challenge clowns! literally ZERO players have EVER done that in the history of football. I used to love this game. Last five years have been utter garbage. I wonder why.

Pros
• The off field management is simply incredible, you can spend hours just managing the first team squad and hiring the right staff members
• Handling finance is also incredible, it's always satisfying to keep a club raking in the millions
• You also get a lot of control when it comes to training players. Molding a wonderkid to be the perfect player has never been better

Negative
• BIG NEGATIVE is the match engine. It's outdated and reeks of garbage.
• First of all the tactics are very one sided. If your not playing a high line, fast tempo, gegenpress your team will struggle.
• Defending is also abhorrent in this game. The Devs decided to balance it out by nerfing Attacking plays resulting in wingers hitting the side netting instead of squaring it, players just shooting the ball from long distance for no reason instead of taking a couple of dribbles and slot it in, and full backs waiting to be closed down resulting in the crosses blocked or losing possession for a counter attack
• Sweeper Keepers are just normal goalkeepers who take more passing risks. Very rarely you see them outside their box and actually SWEEP the god damn ball.
• Pace is also very important for attacking players as through balls over the top of defenders is op. Doesn't matter if the passer terrible he'll turn into prime xavi and find that pacey striker from 30 yards

Up to you, yes FM21 has flaws as most games have but nothing that deters you from persevering - overall If you're a stats person and like to analyse data and toggle and tweak it to your liking - this game is for you.

I'm a long time fan of SI's Football Manager games. They are by far the best in the market for football managing sims. Unfortunately, years have caught up to the software and it evolved into something else.

First, huge props to programmers having to deal with 20 years of legacy code, dubious frameworks and all other challenges of preserving and upgrading this enormous project. Development cycle of these games isn't long enough for meaningful changes and bug fixing. It's very hard to come up with something new, implementing it and having it completely tested on a yearly basis which could lead into things getting very stale and unexpected exploits appearing. There are also problems bleeding from one yearly version to next and so on.

These games suffer mostly from years and years of problem solving and innovating for the sake of innovation and bigger sales. Because of many overpowered exploits, or sometimes need to bring something new each year, things get overly complicated and some features get gutted. For example, in older versions corners were overpowered, so to make them more realistic we now have set piece routines that need to be set up before every single match if you want to have a chance at scoring them. Of course, you can save those routines but they are dependent on your players that you rotate almost every single match every season. Training was very simple and somewhat effective, but to add some sauce it got reworked and now it's kinda impossible to mold players to your will, improving specific attributes needed to take them to a new level. Meanwhile AI has almost free reign in developing their wonderkids. "Realism" is used at will to justify many creative decisions. Yet FM presents unrealistic scenarios all the time. Not only in match engine, but for example with man management. Would a player with loyal personality throw a fit after bid from a barely higher reputable team gets rejected? Would professional personalities try to turn whole dressing room against manager for not getting a contract they required with astronomical demands? To me at least, fun is much more important than the realism.

The challenge of FM games can be as difficult as you wish. Everything is possible with enough time and dedication. There are pre-made tactics which are so overpowered you don't even need to build any, if that's how you wish to manage. As time passes the games sadly boil down to recruitment (having better players than the rest) and going through the same motions which is inherently the biggest flaw of designing games like these. Unfortunately they will eventually become a chore regardless of how fun the challenge started. 

My frustration mostly comes from encountering same irritating things that kill the fun for me:
[list]
    [*]Transfers are a nightmare. If you are already very rich club you have nothing to worry about. But if you care about managing finances, you will have to deal with disgusting demands of players and AI teams. AI teams will lowball you when buying and rip you off completely when selling. AI teams will trade fairly between themselves and players will accept much lower contracts compared to what they demand from you. Worst part is that other teams will destroy your squad harmony and upset your biggest performers in order to buy them, only to not play them more than 10 games over 3 years before selling them on a bloated contract.
    [*]Wingers waiting for defenders to cover them, so they can blast a cross right into those defenders leading to corner number 53.
    [*]The amount of micromanaging stuff. You do have option of delegating things to other staff members but they will always do a below par job. Letting your assistant manager lead training could sometimes damage your match preparations and lead to multiple season long injuries. This is a management game, yes, but the amount of control and systems is simply very high and to play optimally you simply have to utilise them all
    [*]In former games, you could simply stack as much Brazilian and Argentinian wonderkids as you want. To nerf this, their wonderkinds became much more expensive and luxurious. So to bypass this, you simply resort to buying cheap Colombian, Peruvian, Chilean (all other South American really) and Eastern European wonderkids.
    [*]Promises to players when buying them are really stupid. Sometimes they will require to play in a role you randomly set on your tactic last match when experimenting. You might never even play that role again and that player probably didn't even play that role ever before. Yet if you don't fulfill those promises, whole squad will turn against you.
    [*]Squad dynamics, morale and player personality systems being completely out of whack. Get out of CL groups as an Eastern European team for 4 years in a row? Say that your goals is getting out of groups again in team meeting and they will jump their guns, get abysmal morale and whatnot thinking it's unrealistic. Every player no matter the personality is just a mercenary that will turn heel at first chance. There's rarely one club players among talented wonderkids (possible if you are 5 star reputation team), and the only thing personality can tell you is how likely will those players improve in the future (if they have potential).
    [*]Reputation system is a bad. You could be winning CL every season for 10 years and your reputation wouldn't increase much. It's very slow and has so many factors in play. 
    [*]Scouts are almost useless. The only good thing they can do is show you huge lists of potential wonderkids that will not become a star players in 9/10 cases. Sometimes you manage to dig a real gem there. Also, scouts' judgement of players ability and potential gives almost exactly the same reports when that grade is above 9.
    [*]Tactics. They are all over the place. AI doesn't need tactical familiarity to counter you yet if you try something new, you will be punished. Defensive tactics are terrible in this installment, leaking goals left and right with not much to offer in counter attacks. Yet AI perfectly parks the bus when it needs. Pre-made 4231 Gegenpress simply stomps the game.
    [*]Some matches are simply not meant to be won. Every now and then comes a match that simply isn't winnable, sometimes not even drawable. I've tried replaying those more than 20 times with many different tactics and results would be similar, despite my lower level sides managing to beat stronger opponents only months prior. 
    [*]Getting FM'd (losing or drawing last minute while dominating the whole game) occurs from time to time but unlike matches above, replaying them will have wildly different outcomes.
    [*]I don't care if real world statistic might back this feature up, but from FM19, present even today in FM21, every time without fail, on a day 2 days away from a matchday, at least one injury occurs. Micromanage every player's training, overload, rest, whatnot, every time, on a day 2 days away from a matchday, dreading message appears in the inbox informing you that at least one of your players (even U19 are included in this black magic) got injured and won't recover in time for said matchday. 
    [*]I dislike how player improvement works. Late bloomers basically don't exist. Jamie Vardy, van Dijk, Mahrez aren't possible as every player's ceiling is determined when they are created. And their development is over when they turn 24. Achievements do not lead to stat improvements which I think should be a feature. It's even realistic...  
[/list]
I've probably missed many other things but it's the gist of it.

I've played this franchise for a few years now, and every year I have the same issue. Once your team starts winning, they don't stop. At a certain point, you've just won the Europa League with Tranmere Rovers, having munched through the English leagues, and think to yourself "this is boring." It's a lovely looking game, sure enough, but all the bells and whistles can't take away from the fact that it's utterly unchallenging. Its no longer a fun game and hasn't been for years since the 2016 edition. 

Loaded up a save as I have some time off work so can really invest into it. Did a full preseason and had to force quit the game after 4 league matches due to the sheer frustration I now always feel when playing it. I hate the phrase 'FM'd' but on this edition (and the last one) its a real thing. Every game is the same. Dominate the game, create more shots, more shots on target and have double the xG of the opponent and either lose or scrape a narrow 3-2 victory with conceding at least 1 goal in the last 10 minutes no matter what tactic you use. 

I've got strikers with 18 composure, 17 shooting who need 4 good chances a game to score a goal but the opposition need 1 or 2 tops. It just feels like its so weighted towards the computer. and against the user. 

I'm not saying i want to win every game 5-0 and it be easy but there is a balance and it hasnt got it anymore. 

On the other side of the coin, its not realistic at all when it comes to player transfers and manager movements. Man City and Chelsea spend circa 300m every year and never break ffp. City spend 150m each on Fati and Mbappe just to use them as impact subs. I tried to buy ilaix moriba from barca and they wanted 150m and he wanted 600k a week, he was then sold to chelsea in the same window for 100m on 200kla week?

The fm series is the perfect game for you if you are the kind of person who likes to look into tactical aspects of football and have a love for the sport.

Though player attributes play a big role for the game, the tactical side of it also takes a big proportion of the factors deciding whether you win or lose in the matches you play.

Although there are new tactical features such as gegenpressing and tiki taka, there are some tactics which are more dominant compared to others. If you get the hang of the game, you can figure out that there are some best response strategies based on the tactics of the opposing team. If you are playing single player, upon realizing this, it kind of gets repetitive after a few seasons. 

Quite a data heavy content game to play (if alot of leagues are included) 

still a great game even when someone in your team asks for a raise in wage or the game decides to take a dump of red tags to your squad.

TLDR:
+ The game is detailed, allowing you to control many aspects of managing a football club, from tactics to locker room dynamics.
- 3D engine feels weird sometimes. Match engine feels like it decides what the outcome of the match should be, not based on the quality of the teams involved, but based on some mysterious dark force.

Full story:
Well, I've spent 96 hours on this game, and I think that's it for me. I know this may sound like a rant, and some may say that I'm frustrated from bad results, but I'll try to be honest and unbiased.

The game interface is extremely detailed and, in my opinion, well designed, albeit a bit confusing at first. You can control a lot of variables, from individual and collective training, to tactics, set pieces, player instructions, team talks, individual player talks, and so on.

The 3D match representation... Well, it isn't the biggest issue I have with the game, but it could be better. In most of my attacking moves, it feels like my winger has a clear opportunity to cross a ball, but he just waits for the opposite wing-back to arrive and crosses the ball against him, so that a corner is conceded. And I get that the 3D graphics are just representing the outcome of whatever the game engine has calculated based on all the variables, including the pace of the winger and the defender, and so on. Even so, one would guess that the engine would try to be as realistic as possible. And I have an insane amount of corners for my team in every match, so that is not realistic.

So, that takes us to the match engine, which is the biggest issue of this game.

I started out as SL Benfica, one of the title contenders in the Portuguese League. I tried to play attacking football throughout the whole season, and mostly succeeded. As I haven't played FM in some time, I wasn't familiar with the whole (enormous) range of tactical options, so the games against my direct rivals were tough. I think I lost most of them in my first season, which is okay. Even so, I won most of the games against inferior teams, and won the title with about 10 pts difference to the 2nd place.

During this first season, there were already some ridiculous results. There was one Champions League match against the weakest team in the group where I dominated most of the match, but lost it with a late winner by the opposition. And that's tough, but that's football, and that happens every once in a while. And I can understand that. Also, in the middle of the season, my team had a dip in performance, which was associated with some problems in the locker room, and that was also realistic. Even then, I was able to pull through most of the matches with some tight wins.

That's not to mention some ludicrous results that happened in some international matches where I was not involved, like Juventus beating Liverpool by 8-0. I mean, that could also happen in real life, but come on.

Something weird I noticed during the first season was that I was suffering one goal in almost every match. Even in matches that I absolutely crushed the opposition, they always managed to find the back of my net at some point in the game. And I get that there could be something wrong with my defense, tactically. I mean, it's weird that it would happen in every match, even when I was winning by five goals, but still. I made several tactical adjustments throughout the season and ended on a strong note, not conceding for like 4 or 5 matches.

And then came the second season.

It started great. I won the supercup trophy with a comfortable win against one of my major rivals. The off season tactical changes and transfers seemed to be working for the better. I won the first three league games comfortably without conceding goals.

And then it happened. In the following match, the game decided that it would put an end to this. I had 30 shots on total, about 15 on target, I hit the woodwork three times (it was even mentioned in the press conference). The opposition had two shots on target and, obviously, in the 80th minute, they scored. I lost 1-0.

I get it, this sometimes happens in football. In one match, maybe. But this continued in my following three matches. I tried to make tactical changes, I tried holding team meetings, and we always dominated the match, I always "put up a fantastic performance" (I'm quoting) according to the mysterious "xG" indicator, which was always "far greater" than that of my opponent, but I still ended up drawing or losing the match. In the 4th match, I was expecting the same to happen, and suddenly, in the 93rd minute, I scored the 1-0. I got up from my chair to celebrate, surely this was the end of the bad lucky streak. I immediately gave my team instructions to try to hold possession and defend the result; with one minute left in the match, there was no way I would lose it now. But in the kickoff, literally from the kickoff, the opposition exchanged two passes, and with the third pass, the ball ended up with their striker and past my defenders, and they scored the equalizer.

This is also football, and it could happen. But I find it really hard to believe.

Even so, my team pulled back together, and we got a couple of wins in the next matches. After that, I played probably my last FM match ever. It was a cup match against a third division team. I was having about 70% ball possession, 12 shots, 6 on target, and was winning 2-0 at the 25th minute. I remind you this was a third division team, vastly inferior to mine. And they were losing by 2-0, with 0 (zero) shots on target at that time. Suddenly, on a goal kick (yes, a goal kick) their keeper makes a pass directly to their striker, he zaps past my central defender and makes it 2-1. I mean, okay. They were lucky. They had barely exchanged two passes until then, but yeah, I could accept that. My team was still the better team. The problem is that this happened two more times. Yes, they scored three times from a goal kick. When the second half started, I was set on reversing this tendency and grabbing the result. But the match engine was having none of that, because this third division team scored two more times, making it 5-2. I remind you, this is a game I was winning comfortably 2-0, and they hadn't even made a single shot on target. Suddenly, they were the best players in the world.

I ended up losing the match 5-4, but that didn't even matter anymore. I can stand one or two of these incredibly improbable events, because that's the beauty of football, but they are improbable for a reason. They don't happen in five consecutive matches. I don't like a game where it feels like the outcome is pre-determined. That i lost the match, not because the oppostion was better, but because the match engine deemed it so. That's why I'll probably never play FM again, at least not until they fix this situation, which I find highly unlikely, to be quite honest.

FM 2021 is a full on upgrade from previous iterations. Yes, like most sports games, it is just a rehash of last year, with a slightly new skin, and some new rosters, however, this years addition adds just a little bit more. The match engine has been completely overhauled since last year, and players make decisions 10 times better, and watching the game feels way more fluid. A lot of bugs that had plagued last years edition, even through the updates and patches, have been completely fixed in this years edition. I loved the simplification of some of the UI, mainly the conversion of the green circles to star ratings that better indicate levels of proficiency at a certain position / role. I am not too fond of the new pep talk system, as I feel sometimes the gestures are not as easy to understand as the emotions that had been in previous iterations, but over time I got used to it, and its been alright. Overall this game, like every iteration of FM is a must have for any hardcore football fan.

So after having this game for about two weeks (and already logging about 100 hrs in it) I feel like I can leave a pretty good beginner review as I have never played a FM game before this one. I am an American who has barely watched a full match of soccer in my life and I still instantly fell in love with this game. The staff delegation system makes it so easy to learn the mechanics and not get too overwhelmed with complexities of this game. The noob friendliness makes it so easy to learn the mechanics one at a time instead of throwing you into the thick of it all at once. You don't even need to watch or really enjoy soccer to get into this game, most of it consists of the backroom aspects such as signing players, scouting, budgeting, gameplans, and much much more. This game has instantly became my new favorite game to play and I recommend it to anyone who likes strategy sims.

Pros:

Cons:

I enjoy the game and love football, however, the game is far too easy, havent played a fm game in years so decided to pick it up. I won every competition with arsenal 4 seasons on the trot, played with millwall and got them promoted top of the league then won the premier league first season then the champions league straight away, with dortmund i didnt lose a match for the two seasons i played. I do have a decent understanding of football tactics but surely this shouldnt happen. I have played an arsenal campaign 5-6 times and always win everything first season in, even with minimal squad changes. I did the 5 main leagues in one career and managed to win the champions league in my first season with each club.
The game really feels far too easy making it relatively boring once you know what youre doing, many interactions feel like pointless clicking. I struggled to find competition from the ai and had to abandon a lot of saves as the AI didnt provide much competition. Gestures seem pointless as once you work it out you just click the right 2-3 eventually becoming a bit of a chore and boring. Would be nice to see more negative things happen with the team off field in order to balance the ease of everything(outside of injuries). 
Would be good if they could make use of several  tactics instead of setting one up and beating everyone with it(certain formations should overpower others more like in rl so that you actually have to 'manage' the team).
I know licensing is an issue but i shouldnt have to delete files just so german players can play in  the german team etc. Being honest the main leagues and main nations are most important, name changes dont upset me too much but national teams with random generated players is just a joke when they come from major footballing nations.
I like the menus and the tactical analysis, I just wish the game was more difficult so i would feel bothered to actually look at it. If its the tactics i created that were overpowered then they should be balanced more as i was using common tactical approaches which are seen throughout modern as occasionally classic football. I find it to be a game that can be very enjoyable when a competitive element exists but winning constantly with ease becomes boring very quickly. Gegenpress with majority of tactics is too overpowered, it needs to be in the game as it is a common tactical approach but should have some weaknesses in game surely?
Overall the game can be very enjoyable but if you understand football, especially the tactical element the game becomes far too easy, big clubs or even decent sized clubs are too easy to manage also. Supposedly a realistic simulator although i am yet to see it.

I have played the football manager and championship manager series going back years and FM21 does not disappoint. It can still be played as in-depth as you want or you can give it a light touch and have some fun without tweaking every dial and knob in the game. 

I go about half-way between the two. I'm very hands on with the senior team, but let my staff handle the U23 and U18 sides and utilise by Director of Football to handle a lot of the contract work which lets me focus on selection, tactics, training and recruitment for the senior team. If you have ever listed to or read the huge amount of information out there about the game then take this one thing away: everything in the game is connected. Having players who suit your tactical system, who have a good work eithic and are great trainers will stand you in good stead. If they can play a bit too then that's great :)

My top tips for having a good save on each area:
Recruitment: Work your scouts and build up your shortlist. Scout everywhere, when they make a suggestion then get them to scout the player and scout them until they are 100% scouted. Be liberal with your trials, there is absolutely no harm in getting a player in for four weeks to see if he's any good. From this you can build up a long shortlist of players which you can instantly turn to when your main striker does his cruciate and is out for a year or you get promoted and need to upgrade your playing staff.
Tactics: Keep it simple. In FM21 game you will often get players saying they are unfamiliar with the tactical setup even though you've been practicing it for months. Play players in the position that best suits your tactical plan, and don't overburden them with instructions, one or two will do, if that. I hardly give players any individual instructions at all. In real life footballers are mostly not tactical geniuses and this follows in the game. Oh and take a little time to create set-piece routines (you don't need to go mad and do them all at once, set up one per quarter of the season, it is a boring thing to do). It will benefit you in the long run, set-pieces are so important in modern football.
Training: It's important to have a training plan, but you need to keep an eye on it and tweak it now and again. I let my assistant handle setting up the training sessions, but if I see something that requires attention I will throw in a session or two to address it. If my team is wasteful in front of goal I might put in a Chance Conversion session. If the upcoming opposition are good from set-pieces (There is loads of analysis available on your opposition and I find watching key highlights from their last match useful) I will put in a session on defending corners.
Selection: It can be hard to keep a large squad happy as they mostly all want to play. I rarely play the same team in consecutive games, changing one or two players each game can help give game time to everyone and keep the players fresh. If a player does become unhappy and starts demanding game time then I will never back down. I'll try and convince them to get their head down and work hard to earn their chance, but if they are adamant then it's my way or the highway. There can only be one boss.

I like the new analysis features, simple things like if you xG is bad, working out a way to get more good chances to my forwards (You can have lots of shots, but low xG a lot of the shots are taken from poor positions). Heat maps can be instructive, are my players playing in the areas I expected?

There's loads to get your teeth into in the game, but try and keep the AI guessing. Think of it as an opposition manager, if you play the same team and tactics every single week regardless of results and opposition then then that opposition manager will work out a way to combat you.

Overall, I have really enjoyed the latest Football Manager iteration so far, some good new useful features while it hasn't lost any of the playability of old.

As good as 10 years ago but with many improvements. Why the negative review then ? A few examples from my play through.

A few matches before the end of season. My most used player who played in 35 games. He was really tired, I benched him for 1 match to give him some rest. He called for a meeting because he want to play more.
In league preview we were supposed to relegate, we made it to play off where we did not promote because of one goal. I told players next year we will promote to increase their mood, all went to depression because the target is just too high.
Youngster asked why I didn't fulfil my promise to loan him to give him real match experience after a season when he started in more than 50% of matches with my team.
And the worst thing that is happening every transfer window. I got very low offer/s for my youngster/s. Board decide to sell because it is great offer. I protest, they told me I can use my transfer budget to find replacement. Equal replacement costs 10x more. Once I saved and put my resignation on table to see the reaction. They told me they want me to stay and therefore will increase transfer budged by the same amount that club received for the sold player. They were selling the player for 1.6m while club had 36m in coffers. Equal replacement was 20m+ And you can make the situation even more absurd. Next transfer window you can buy some of them back for 10x more.

There were more non sense complain from players or weird reactions, I don't remember them all.

I bought this game out of nostalgia for the 2002 Premier League manager game I used to play as a kid. I expected a nice, fun and easy going game where I could buy and sell some players, hire some staff, arrange the team press skip and see how they do. I even hoped that in doing this I could find some fun "video game logic" that I could exploit and create something ridiculous.

That was my mistake. This isn't a game, it is a job simulator of the most hellish sort of job I can imagine.

[list]
[*] An unreadable number of emails to read each day
[*] Agents and other clubs setting extortionate and ridiculous demands in negotiation (think 10x the advertised price) on rubbish players
[*] Excessively complicated training schedules to manage
[*] Managing players' emotions (seriously?)
[*] Losing every match your team plays unless you put in a massive amount of time for all the above
[/list]

I'm sure a lot of you sickos enjoy that sort of thing, but be warned: THIS IS NOT A GAME

It pains me to write this but after spending more than 400 hours I have to admit: it's a poorly designed game with artifical difficulty spikes designed to keep players engaged. You can be the by far best team in the league and you will always have a seasonal rival (undocumented in-game) which will keep the pace with you. You can be a heavy-weight in a small league and there will be a team which is not better than any other in competitions which will go with the same results as you. 

Worst part when the game decides that it should boost your real rival. I have just one example of it: playing in UPL with Shakhtar I managed to finish the season with 28 wins and 2 draws in the 30 games. Guess what was the gap with Dynamo Kiev? 2 points. The third place was like 20 points lower. A season before I lost the league to Vorskla - it had lost points in 4 games through the whole season and my only loss was to them. I had numerous finishings in previous seasons with different teams when on the last match day the leader was losing, my team coming second won and then the third team became the first on goal difference, winning 5-0 and scoring its last goal on the last minutes in injury time. I get that it happens in football, see Man City and Aguero, but not in the course of couple of seasons in a row.

Apart of that the game is addicting as ever although SI doesn't care for bug fixing (top managers have like perpetual contracts, in my 15 season save Simeone, Conte, OGS, Pochettino and Flick ALL were managing their starting cubs) and their UI designer clearly hates people - I can't find any reason to make the UI overloaded mess in dark purple color. In 2021 SI didn't even care to add additional skins leaving it to fans. Really, you become so lazy? You had to tweak a couple of lines of code to do that.

Match engine looks much better until you realize that it relies heavily on the patterns. If you get that patterns, you can exploit it, and if you want to keep it natural you will face artificial difficulty spikes. Maybe in 2000s it was the same, I don't know, it all felt like an unscripted free flow and now you can guess the outcome of episode 90% times the 3D field appears.

Tactics make no sense, as you can't play defensive football relying to soak the pressure - it's instantly punished by the opposition. Players with 5 in long shots suddenly pull of Roberto Carlos if you play defensive and there is no way to explain it but the match engine flaws. If the game decides that it's time to score, it will score. To play attacking you should do counter-intuitive things (deep defensive line and low pressure against the last team in a league is a must or you will be heavily beaten with the magic 30-meter screamers).

On top of that you have the SI community forums with extremely gatekeeping audience which is intolerable to any criticism of their game. Moderators delete negative comments claiming they welcome meaningful discussion and constructive criticism. Like, I'm a paying customer who gets banned for stating that I'm not that happy with what I've payed for. In all my years online I've never seen more toxic and hostile community - even Reddit is friendly and supportive in comparison. Think twice before sponsoring it. I was a big fan of FM in 2005 - 2012 editions, I haven't really played for 8 years and I had over 700 extremely frustrating and unrewarding hours in 2020/21 versions. I won't buy it before they fix the UI and fire their UI designer. I can't possibly recommend the game which is made with the goal to frustrate the players and encourage exploits.

I finally upgraded to FM21 after skipping FM19 & 20 - mostly it was the xG feature that piqued my interest, but I also like to update every so often for little things like competition rule/qualification changes, refreshing rosters, etc. Coming from FM18, I've been pleasantly surprised at some of the new features added in FM21 - not only do I really enjoy the xG thing, I love the overall improvement in what I'd call "realism": The interaction with staff continues to get better and better, the way staff and management present you with reports and call meetings is awesome, and the scouting meetings before transfer windows are so damn cool. It all combines to make you feel like you're actually a manager and not just playing a game. I'm at around 230 hours of FM21 and I'm still constantly finding myself engaging with new things. 

Last, I'd just like to share my experience/thoughts on scum-saving. For the most part during my thousands of hours of FM over the years, I felt like I was pretty fair about reloading matches - I only tended to do it if I had a bad injury to a star I'd just signed, or conceded a BS glitch/bug goal, etc. Sometimes if I was having a bad day and fired up FM only to be down 4-0 to Man City in the 35th minute I'd just Ctl-Alt-Delete and replay the match a few days later. But with my new save in FM21, I've been experimenting with a strict no-save-scumming policy, and it's added a whole new compelling element to my gameplay. I had a real stinker of a game against Newcastle (5-0 I think) - the sort of game I'd have been tempted to reload in the past - and a day later my players refunded the supporters' tickets for the match. How cool is that!? I also got to within one bad result of getting sacked, and had to get something away at Sheffield Utd - what a nerve-racking match that was! My boys pulled out a 3-1 win to keep me alive, and we had a short run of good form to finish the season, allowing me to get the transfer reinforcements I desperately needed. 

So TL;DR: FM is hands down the best sports management sim on the market, I felt it was well worth the money to upgrade from FM18 to FM21, and if you've never experimented with a no-save-scum policy - give it a whirl. I think you'll find it rewarding.

The best Football Manager since 12. If you are new to the series or like me you wait a few years before updating FM it's a bit overwhelming at first with all its features and opportunities to micro-manage. There are good tutorials for everything, but more importantly you can delegate everything to your assistant until you're ready to tackle each thing one at a time, and you won't suffer any real consequences from it.

The matches feel real (which is a welcome change!), and maintaining a good run of form, getting the result that gets you out of a losing run, preparing for a big match, all of it feels insanely real. The stakes feel really high and I feel far more tense than I ever have playing Football Manager.

It is also lightning fast on my laptop, even 10 seasons in, where previous editions have been a struggle. In every department, this is a high-water mark for FM. If you had gotten bored of the series like me, this will relight that fire.

Imagine playing Leeds on the final day of the season as Brighton manager. Your best player and top goalscorer is missing through injury. You must beat Leeds to win the league after an outstanding season. its 0-0 but then Leeds strike in the 67th minute to go 1-0 up. You begin your heart starting to break. But then out of nowhere, Lewis Dunk rises from a corner on the 79th minute to equalise. There's a glimmer of hope restored. Man Utd fans hear of your equaliser in their game and become anxious. The 90th minute arrives and its still 1-1. You can hear Man Utd's fans celebrating already. You have a freekick on the edge of the box though ..... MacAllister steps up. ITS IN!!!!! Its the last kick off the game!! The beer you have in your hand which was meant to drown your sorrows goes everywhere in celebration, including over your best suit which you was wearing because its such an iconic moment in Brighton FC's history!

This is what this game gives you. Moments like this!

Love this game version. It`s more realistic, and have more good stuff during the match, you now have a bar along the bottom featuring your starting XI and an at-a-glance look at key info like their mindset, fatigue, with a very good 'touchline tablet' to hand at all times for looking at analytics, formations and highlights in more detail. The changes here are mostly excellent - more realistic and more usable.

The pre-match and post-match briefings are similarly more detailed, and I'm a big fan of the added post-match screens that show the reaction on social media, next to other results and a glimpse of the table. 

This year’s match engine is where I find everything comes together and the best way to learn about my squad is to see them in action, watching (and often, shouting) from the sidelines as their training, mental preparedness, and interpersonal dynamics all come together into a single performance. Football Manager 2021 hasn’t really rocked the boat in terms of enhancing the matchday gaming experience from last year. Games are as  difficult as ever to manage, and the minutiae of detail is just as overwhelming as always. Rather than a complete overhaul, there are numerous minor tweaks in Football Manager 2021, affecting tactical exploration and simulation. This time around, energy levels in particular seem to play a greater role, presumably to combat previously effective pressing tactics. In other words,  you can’t rely on your tried-and-tested methods from last year to get by.

Football Manager 2021‘s biggest change seems to come in the way that you, as a Manager, communicate. Gone are the meaningless emotions while addressing people; instead, your decisions are broken down into what really matters. While talking to players, the boardroom or press, you can respond in a much more clear way. You’ll be able to choose from responses that are positive, negative, convincing, or even backing down. Better yet, the intended meaning of everything you say is clearly laid out.

The communication overhaul really adds a lot to how you are judged as a manager in Football Manager 2021. Yes, results are still important, but you can really change the parameters of what your personal success is. If you aren’t doing especially well but are achieving the promises you have set out, you will be given more time.

This happened to me; in my first season of managing, I had slightly underachieved. But because I had delivered on my promise to repair the financial damage of the over bloated squad, I wasn’t kicked out at the end of the season where I might’ve been in previous instalments. The next season, having been able to gain control of the finances, I was able to cultivate success. This is a new experience for me in a Football Manager game; a series I’ve been playing for over a decade. While I may have improved the finances of a club before, I have never overtly communicated my goals to the boardroom and insisted on time to deliver.

Football Manager 2021 has done something that great managers do: it has acknowledged its weaknesses and improved upon them without completely rocking the boat. It still feels truly familiar as a Football Manager game, but the overhaul to expectations and communication makes for a more coherent and impactful experience. There’s more of a focus on what you say and do in your role as a manager and, over seasons, your performance is better judged. It makes a real difference to how the game can play out. The matchday experience may not be massively improved, but the improved focus elsewhere makes a real difference. For anyone who truly likes to get into the role of manager, Football Manager 2021 is a must.

I've been playing this game since the early days of Championship Manager (and more sporadically in more recent years). All I can observe with any clarity is the fact that the fun element disappears year after year in place of supposedly 'realistic' aspects of management. They aren't realistic at all, they are superficial, piecemeal, callow notions of realism. All that made CM fun in the first place was doing your tactics, buying your players and watching the match. The trainspotter/statto/micromanagement mire of modern incarnations is testament to the ridiculous fanboy deference so many people have to the monopolisation of this genre by Sports Interactive. How about they actually release something that's fun? How about they stop acting like Adobe with yearly incarnations of Photoshop and stop introducing pointless measures of tedium just to justify taking £40 off you each your for the same game? Boring, tedious, not a simulation, not a fun game either.

As always, the newest version of FM is bit better than the earlier one. I have played since 93 I think and still enjoy the game. However, I don't purchase every new FM, only every second. Last one I played was fm19 and fm17 before that. It seems the developers are bit lazy for bringing in new features and removing or fixing features that don't quite work and therefore getting every second new version is enough. 

An example: The team talk is still practically the same as it was 4 years ago. New comments are rare and you get very quickly bored when asked the same questions over and over and over again. AI is poor in the questions as well. Last question before my CL final was a random team in the same league putting a random player on transfer list and asking if I agree with the decision or not. The impact of answers seems minor as well yet it features now more often than ever. At least in the new version you can safely let the assistant manager handle them not risking everybody getting angry when they say silly things. 

Another (small) example: Negotiating a new contract with your club. As it has been years now, they don't budge at all. They offer something regardless of how well you have managed the team and asking even "one tick" more results them just offering the original sum until you either accept it or don't get new contract. So you can make the team best in the world winning CL many times in a row and the salary stays at the same, or you leave. Just a minor thing but annoying.

So basically a very good game as always with minor improvements from FM19 (match engine is really cool from time to time and removing % and putting hearts in condition for example is way better and realistic) but if SI wants us to buy every new version coming up yearly, they should have little more effort than just updating the database

Each year i have to spend a few weeks playing this game for 6+ hours a day. That's just how it works, you get pulled in.

Simply put, there wasn't enough development between this and 2020.  It seems some behind the scenes stats were exposed and some UI changes were made but ultimately you're looking at a full price roster upgrade, ala the FIFA series.

Same huge flaws as last year: maximum aggression gegenpressing is ludicrously effective and it's incredibly difficult to get any other style of play to work properly.  Most of the options (tactics, training etc.) feel like a series of traps rather than a way to get your team to play the way you want.  Every little tweak sends your players' behaviour off in a wildly exaggerated direction.  Pick one of the handful of combinations that work and you'll do well every time.  Most combinations produce awful results.  Press conferences are still repetitive, dull and relentless, but sending your asst manager feels oppressively suboptimal.  The social media guff is repetitive and often makes no sense.

If I had to guess, I'd say that a few years back SI made the decision to limit control over player behaviour to prevent people from making overpowered tactics that broke the match engine, which has resulted in them... breaking their own match engine and sucking a lot of the fun out of this game which was once such a joy.

edit:  I gave it a fair go, ten seasons.  It's just so bad.  Players behave like they've never seen a football in their lives, making the *exact* same stupid movement combinations over and over.  SI have had literally two decades to perfect this, and yet somehow it gets worse every year.
Just keep getting better every year

FM 21 is the perfect managerial game for perfectionists and control freaks. At first, you may need to get past the awkwardness of the user interface, the general quirks and kinks, and the shock of the sheer amount of detail you may control. Once that happens tho, it's a terrific satisfying experience when things are going well, and incredibly frustrating when they aren't. If you get frustrated easily, or if reading isn't your thing at all, or if you simply don't have much free time, this game might not be for you. If you're someone who is a perfectionist, enjoys football/soccer, and loves to tinker with ideas, this game will eat up your days. Seriously tho, unless you delegate some tasks to the coaching staff you eventually hire or inherit, you will put serious hours in. Be ready, jump in, learn as you go, and get lost

I've been playing Football Manager for a long time. Combining the hours of all my games, this series would be number one on play time.

I skip every couple of years, because no matter how good these games are not much changes on a year to year basis. I've held off from buying for a little bit longer because I saw all the reviews these last couple of years about the "match engine" but honestly have had no problems.

The game runs really well, feels really good, and more importantly is a lot of fun. I enjoy some of the new stats/analysis they've given us, as well as amount of talent that get's generated 10 seasons+ into the game. in the past I've noticed that once the non-generated players have gone in the past, that sometimes good players were harder to find. Not for the players, but for the rest of the clubs. I enjoy that despite developing some of my players for 5 seasons, I still am challenged by other teams. In the past I felt like the game turned into a steam roller once you got enough talent. This is the first game that I've played where it's still challenging me.

Definitely worth getting!

As a newcomer to the Football Manager series, getting over the hump of the first few playing sessions was both boring and tedious as you are lost in doing menial tasks while learning how to play. Then, as you begin to further understand the game, the game begins to be very fun and rewarding for the effort you put in. Overtime the player begins to have a real sense of ownership with the team you may choose to manage and therefore focus even more on the crazy levels of detail and customization that the game offers. It begins to feel like a game of "just one more turn". On top of that, strong community support offers even more content and bang for your buck. Football Manager 2021 might feel similar or repetitive to previous installments, as said by other reviews, but it is a fantastic version that offers a lot to newcomers like myself. I may be 500 hours in myself at the time of this review, but I feel like i'm still at the beginning of my first play-through.
Do you look at Bielsa and think 'If I was fatter, I could do his job.'? Me too. Apart from the fat bit. I'm grotesque enough as it is.

It's an... odd one. 

At the core it's a spreadsheet, you won't be controlling a player and using them or anything like that - it's strictly a game about managing. A lot of numbers, a lot of looking at numbers and, at least at first, a lot of trial and error until you work out to game the various mechanics and such.

What's really odd about is that it's not boring. Given you're basically staring at an excel spreadsheet for a few hours before a match happens it's oddly enjoyable.

I will say though the press related stuff that happens in game, as well as player interaction in general is repetitive, dull and utterly meaningless in any real sense. At first it's fairly immersive... until you realise they're the same questions and issues repeated forever. 

It's a background process I feel. Something to be turned on whilst watching a tv show or waiting for a raid to start etc, not a game to focus on in and of itself.

I bought almost every single Football Manager game and I can comfortably say that this will be the last one until there is a new game to challenge FM. They claim to add new features in the game but all it does is over-complicating it, rather than fixing the actual issues. 

Years after years the game has never changed because the scenarios are always the same. I don't even think they bothered to change some codes for maybe 10 years. Outcomes are predictable and the game feels scripted as hell.

And the bugs.. Imagine a "simulation" where a team scores a goal, it's not offside, it's not canceled, no VAR review, players celebrate it, it is even on the replay after the game, but it is not registered on the scoreboard. I wouldn't even mentioned this if it happened once but it happened 3 times in a single career so I assume it's not a rare bug at all.

Wouldn't give half a star to rate this game.

The match engine does not represent the scoreline, as it's been the main problem since CM days. You would create a hell of a lot more chances but lose anyway, if your tactic is not meant to win according to the engine.

When you complained about this back in the old days, people would say in the forums that your chances are probably not that valuable, or most of your shots probably were long shots, they've come up with any type of excuses. Because there were some people constantly winning games, and you were not winning, so the problem must've been about you.

But now we have xG. Now we can prove that the match engine is flawed, and no matter how much big chances you create, you will lose that match if the engine thinks your tactic is bad. You are watching the matches for nothing. If you watch the match you will think that your tactic is superior, but if you check the scoreline you are losing. And it is impossible to understand just by watching your matches that your tactic should change to win, because everything is in order if you don't look at the scoreline.

I am also playing the games on 2D engine, because the 3D engine kills my love of football. The players act like someone took their brain out, the shots and pass physics are a joke, and the marking and initiative skills of the players are equal to a 3 year old kangaroo's. Even the net starts shaking before the ball goes into the net. With 2D engine, at least I can still use my imagination and think that the makers are not robbing us year after year.
