Also the game is not cheap so fucking get all the shirts and badges from the top competitions in there, when we do sloppy work we get fired, some guys over at your company deserve to get sacked.

Pros - 
1. Gives you in depth knowledge about the footballing world tactics, about player growth, management of club at an overall level. Very close to real life club management.
2. Live tactical changes and side line shouts to make your team going and keeping them up and running all the time.
3. Real time transfers with a social section where the system has created bots which give opinion on a specific transfer and all about their fan clubs. The rumour mill ( xD ).

Lets get to the cons -
1. The extensive features of the game make it quite difficult for new players to where to start from! Referring to you tube videos to - "How to get started with FM21" is the right thing.
2. As a FIFA player, the transfer concepts to me were quite simplistic. But this game has totally made me mad! The transfer of a player is such a tedious procedure. Specially big name transfers!, the club does not leave them. Better refer to videos where you can sign good potential players.
3. The worst! Club names, player faces and the UI, you might get sick of it and after some time you will be pissed off! The ManU logo of my club had me going all through videos and setting up all the stuff for myself

BUT AS A WHOLE - " THIS IS NOT A GAME! THIS SHIT IS REAL. I HAVE PURCHASED IT BECAUSE OF THE REVIEWS, IF YOU ARE LOOKING TO STICK TO ONE DEDICATED FOOTBALL GAME AND HAVE A LIKING FOR TRANSFERS AND STUFF! HERE YOU ARE! THE SOCIAL FEED HYPE GETS YOU GOING!"

It becomes pointless in the end. 
1. You can't beat Liverpool or Man City no matter what system you try unless you are managing an equally big club full of superstar players. Believe me I've tried. They both appear to spend massive amounts on players every summer without selling hardly anyone. Liverpool now have Haarland, Jota, Firmino and Salah up front. Totally overpowered.
2. Too many goalmouth scrambles and GK's who can't hold onto a shot but deflect it to another opposition player to tap in.
3. Too much derping around when a cross is clearly on. Pull backs don't exist. But trying a shot while standing on the byline does.
4. Every VAR offside decision is correct but you still have to watch while the AI goes through the motions.
5. There seems to be more attacks in the four or five minutes of injury time than there are in the rest of the match put together. Hence a lot of goals are scored late.
6. Refs dishing out yellow cards from the first minute. The AI recommends hard tackling and after three or four of your players have been booked it says ease off tackling. FFS.
The fact is after three or four seasons you end up with a bloated squad of grumbling players all  and the youngsters are useless so you just start again. Maybe it's just best to manage the big super rich clubs and just crush everyside you come up against.

After a surprise promotion run that saw a team that was seeded bottom of the table win playoffs and get promoted to the next league, the Sky Bet League Two, Phoenix National found out what it really meant to be in another league. They were handed loss after loss, and could only barely eke out draws occasionally. It wasn't long before, mid season, they were bottom of the table. Meanwhile their promotion partners, Notts Co, who had also come up from the lower leagues with them, was showing their true talent as a top of the league team. By mid season they were placed #1, Phoenix National at the bottom #24

Head coach Cope decided then to radically change his tactics. He abandoned the defensive, passive style of football he'd taught for the last season and a half and switched to an incredibly aggressive possession style of football that truly controlled the pace of the game. Phoenix national got their first win. And then another. An unbeaten string of games from mid-season all the way up into a surprise playoff contention spot just barely squeezing in at #7 after an incredible run that included a 4-0 rout of a team that had previously crushed them

Notts Co had always been a difficult match for Phoenix National, but Phoenix beat them in a surprising 2-1 game, shocking the attendees. And then. Playoffs came. The very first match saw #3 seed Notts Co vs Phoenix National #7. In a tight first game, Phoenix just barely got the better of their rivals in a 2-1 game, and drew the second winning by aggregate. Then Phoenix went on to rout the playoff finalists Southhampton in a 3-0 crushing victory, securing themselves a second promotion in a row. Phoenix National had truly risen from the ashes.

As a game, there are the occasional bugs and problems, I've seen a couple clipping errors. But as a story-making device, as a simulation, it's phenomenal. Creating your own club, taking a bottom-of-the-league team and turning them into a success story, watching your striker go from goal drought to rainforest, cheering when your players win after a hard-fought penalty kickoff. Where FM21 really shines is how it makes you attached to each one of your players, and riveted by their growth.

I love the game, except for one major flaw; the match engine's hard coded bad streak / good streak mechanic. No matter what you do after a good run there will be one match a season, veterans will know the match I am talking about, where all of your players become limp fish on the pitch and lose form at exactly the same time. And before the hardcore fans come out and say "oh it's complacency" no, it's not there is not a single player with a complacent body language and everything has been done to reduce potential complacency. Messi's dribbling turns into Peter Crouch, Kompany's defending becomes like Ozil, and world class players just watch the ball go past them, hit the woodwork all of the time, miss every 1o1, cross the ball into defenders more often, pass the ball long straight back to the other team even though you have defensive short passing on, injuries to the best players etc etc. It's pretty much the same as the FIFA scripted mechanic. 

Then after this one match, the next 10 or so will become extremely difficult, and no change in tactic, roles, swapping in players, match talks, press talks... nothing will change this mechanic. The form is hard coded in the game and there's nothing you can do about it. Some people will say this is like real life; teams go through bad forms, and that is true, but the question is do we want to play a game which forces a bad form onto you which is completely out of your control, or would you prefer to have some influence over the bad form? This bad form will hit once a season on average, no matter what you do, consistent rotation or no rotation, changing tactics to adapt to the AI, or keeping them consistent it doesn't matter. Alot of people also respond to this criticism by saying, "the AI adapts to your tactics after a while if you are winning", and the AI does change their tactics, but them changing their tactics has nothing to do with why your team suddenly can't pass forwards without an interception, or they stand and watch the ball go past, or dribble straight into the opposition players, or hit the woodwork or get injured at 300% rate than normal, or suddenly can't make a first touch anymore, or their crosses hit the opposition and create a corner and you know all 1o1's will end badly during this form. Most of this has nothing to do with the opposition tactics, just because they went counter attack, shouldn't mean my players all lose 10 to their dribbling, passing, first touch, positioning stat for 10 games. 

The next response to this I see often is "what incentive would SI have to put such a mechanic in the game?"
Because commercial incentives developers have in keeping their customers coming back every year. SI can't make the same game every year with an updated roster and a couple differences in the UI and match engine without generating an addiction in their customers. This bad/good form streak creates an actual dopamine psychological addiction, similar to loot boxes in other games or player cards in FIFA. The reward in this game is good form, and a feeling that you have overcome something which was prior out of your control. When you regain the good form streak, where now all your players dribble like Messi, and shoot like Lewandoswki, you feel like you are responsible. 

The human condition of contrast effect (is the enhancement or diminishment, relative to normal, of perception, cognition or related performance as a result of successive (immediately previous) or simultaneous exposure to a stimulus of lesser or greater value in the same dimension) creates a much larger sense of achievement when we get into a good form relative to the out of control bad form. Doubly it has an additional contrast effect as we feel like the game is out of our control during the bad form (external locus of control), and in control (internal locus of control) during the good form creating a massively exaggerated sense of being in control during the good form and we experience a dopamine feedback loop for the good form as we, without cognitive awareness, compare it to the experience and external locus of control of the bad form. 

SI used to have an addiction rating in the game based on the number of hours you played, they are well aware of how dopamine responds to this contrast effect of psychological states of external and internal locus of control. I worked in insurance gamification, so even more morally bankrupt than EA with FIFA, and they are very aware of mechanics for creating addictions in the customers. It's a business, it would be poor business management and product development if they didn't find a way to get customers coming back every year. SI would without a doubt have KPI's and OKR's and targets for customer retention every year, so the department responsible for hitting these targets would be probably the ones responsible for keeping these frustrating game mechanics in the game. Add to this that this bad form also creates an artificial difficulty spike which keeps the game engaging for veterans, who would stop buying the game if they found it too easy every iteration. 

This mechanic is actually not as bad as in FM2020, but it is still there and I doubt they will be removing it any time soon. I probably wouldn't have played this one for so long without the sense of achievement I had in being better at this one than FM20 which had even more bad form/good form mechanics. But my skeptical mind tells me they make each iteration in a rotation of difficulty to keep that addiction fed. FM22 will probably be more difficult again, and FM23 will be easier, so they generate a long term meta contrast effect, and we feel more in control in this version relative to the last so we enjoy it again, then it's too easy so they make the next game more difficult and frustrating again. Cycle repeats. It's actually good game design if you don't notice it, but once you notice it, you can't really go back in good faith realizing you are just actually psychologically addicted to the cleverly crafted dopamine cycles. 

And if you think it's not possible to be psychologically addicted to a game, gamblers on the slot machines have been shown to have actual similar dopamine responses to winning as people have to hard drugs. Think about that before you buy a game that intentionally gets you addicted. SI are no better than gambling companies, they just use a different psychological effect to get you addicted, just instead of money as the reward they give you a sense of inflated control relative to the bad streak.. which come to think of it is the same as a slot machine. To your brain there is no difference between winning money and winning a sense of control, they represent the same thing. 

The problem is if they made this mechanic transparent, it wouldn't have the same addictive effect, the same way knowing that a slot machine will ALWAYS hard coded give you a return of 96% on your $1, most people who realized this don't gamble. This game does the same with their hard coding of streaks, and once it's become transparent it doesn't have appeal anymore. So they need to keep it intransparent to keep the game engaging, and we will forever be frustrated at that bad streak until we liberate ourselves with the knowledge that this bad streak is intentionally there to keep you interested, and spending more money.

I was skeptical as I'd never played a true "management sim" before, though I do like soccer in real life and also have played EA's FIFA most years. This game has me hooked - I never thought I would be well over 100 hours in to be honest but it is very well done and has a crazy amount of depth. I've also learned a great deal about soccer because of it. Something to note is that you can automate all the parts of running teams that you don't enjoy e.g. transfers, match day's, lower tier team management, etc. This makes it easy to pick up and work your way into controlling more of the day to day as you get comfortable. Really great game, would absolutely recommend.

The most underrated and rarely mentioned part of this game is the match day engine that actually allows you to influence and watch your players in real time as they face the other teams on game day. It's full 3d and looks pretty good. I've now played some other management sims e.g. Out of the Park Baseball and they don't even come close to actually making the matches/games look good compared to FM21. The FM21 match engine is one of my favorite features and is very rewarding after you've spent hours before each match tweaking your lineups and tactics to see your players in real time do their best to bring your side the win. I find myself watching full matches now sitting on the edge of my chair and shouting at my players both in real life and in the game when they make mistakes or celebrating when they find the back of the goal. Absolutely would recommend.

I appreciate the game very much. Many compliments to those who have the skills and dedication to put such a intricate product together and make it available to football enthusiasts the world over. Muchas gracias to all who do this. Please know that this product is quite the handy educator. Yes, in addition to being  an enjoyable freetime pastime, this game helps educate us all on the world through seeing league structures in different countries and even learning some geography. After all, it is interesting to look up where some of these smaller clubs play in such countries as Spain, in Ireland, in places in Scandinavia, Greece, Eastern Europe and throughout all of South America and Asia.  That is one suggestion I would like to make.  A map included which shows the cities of the participating clubs within a given country.  For example, in the Netherlands, a map showing the clubs of the Eredivisie and then another for the second league.  Or perhaps just one map.  Red dots indicate the top flight clubs, blue dots the clubs of the second division.  Perhaps the next tier down in green dots too? Yes?  Yes, something like this.  This really can be quite the educational tool.  Plus, in Spain it lets me know how far I'll actually be travelling with the team when leaving the Basque Country to play away in Murcia, Almeria or Cartagena  down south on the Med coastline.  Las Palmas too ;)  In a country like Italia, it helps with the appreciation of lower league clubs having the expense of travel requirements.  It also helps better appreciate why local rivalries have emerged over time in countries or regions we football enthusiasts do not know so well. My only quibble with your game in this 2021 version is the lack of a light skin and middle, neutral skin.  The darkness of the overly dark purple  only in-game skin is very poor. It's frankly cheap.  Surely you know that it is difficult on the eyes.  The only thing that has saved this year's game is those who make the effort to create Workshop Community skins and share them with the rest of us.  You can have the greatest sports management game on the planet right now, but it is only a fraction of its real worth without a variety of skins to help the gameplayers find what suits them best.  All of your hard work is meaningless unless your products is very welcoming, very pleasantly visible. Please take this into account and make real accommodations to honour those who spend their money and time on your product. Thank you.  (Hint:  It is never too late; please go ahead and add an official FM21  Light Skin for this 2021 game. You'd be instant heroes worldwide for doing so - I mean it. You'll also increase the number of people purchasing this product. Cheers!)  Yes,  FM 2021 is an overall very intriguing product that offers the sports interested a completely different view into the world of global football.  Thank you for doing it and offering this manager game as a means to enjoy The Beautiful Game.

Disclaimer: All I know about football is you have a ball and two teams, and you're trying to get the ball into the other teams net. You also have goal keepers. That's literally it. SO this review will be from that perspective.

Football Manager 2021 is the first FM game I've played, and honestly.... one of the first sports manager games I've played. I've always had an interest in them, even though I don't follow sports, but FM21 is my first jump in. 

So As a complete novice in every respect I jumped into FM21 with the head cannon of "I'm a stratagist in a massive army fighting against many other armies." This honestly did help me a lot to get to grips. I'm not learning a new sport, I'm learning something I'm familiar with.

And teach is something that FM21 does... decently. This game is a text heavy. There is no voice overs, no videos, it's just text explaining all the text. It's honestly a lot to take in especially if you don't know what team formations are. What is a 2-4-4-2 tiki? I don't know. And there's hundreds of different formations. The game doesn't tell you what this is. But it does have a thumbs up to tell you "Hey, you're team is pretty well equiped for this formation. Use it."

And that is one extremely nice thing about the management side of things. You can deligate off basically everything to the AI if you don't want to deal with it. Training, scouting, contract nagotiations, almost all of it can be given to the AI at any time and you can take it on any time. This creates a nice enviorment that you can focus on 2 things at once, and than introduce whatever next and it doesn't seem to really affect the team, at least not in any ways that new comers will notice.

That being said there is a lack of explanation with some things. For instance, during the simulated matches, you watch from the side lines and can give out callouts. Things like praise, scold, ect. Now you would think praising the team after a goal would be a good thing. A nice "Awesome job guys! Keep it up!" but NO! Praising after a goal for some reasons lowers moral during the game. I've had them at great and drop to discouraged. I guess it's something to do with praise actually being something else and you need to wait to praise until the last quarter. There's no real in game explination, just people relaying what they've figured out.

In terms of how welcoming this game is to new players I'd say it's pretty decent. The hardest things will be all the info related to the sport. Knowing what teams are good, what players are good, what formations are good, what skills to look for for whatever spot you're trying to fill. But it really does have that addicting managment simulator gameplay, so even if you don't like sports that much there's still a ton of depth to be found.

However the absolute lack of sounds is a hit against the game. A lack of voice acting is sad, but no music, no sound effects when changing tabs or emails or anything is just... off putting. I cranked my volume thinking something was wrong, only for a match day to start with suddenly cheers and noises to blast through my headphones. It makes the game a really silent and boring time.

Overall though I do recommend this game if you're a managment simulator fiend like me. Be it that you know every football player on the pitch today or you only know the ball goes in the net. There's a ton of depth and a very big and active community to help you along the way. It is a bit quite and doesn't fully explain everything to you, but it does a good job of getting it's teeth into you and holding you there.

If you want your team to perform to the max, make sure you add each one of the match preparation once a week at least to the training and the team bonding one as well under extras. Every single week. Except maybe match practice one, your assistant will include that one when appropriate anyway. 

You can leave it to the assistant for creating the rest and just add/tinker these in using the "change once" confirmation. Do not take out match preview or recovery ones though. 

Do not be afraid to just add these instead of a rest as these are not demanding schedules. (I happily train all 3 sections daily except the day before a match and most of the time after)

This will mesh your team together, make them perfect your tactic and team bonding one will create partnerships (the green lines) so quickly you won't believe it. 

You are welcome.

My recommendation of FM 21 is based on the fact that it´s still a good game based on the foundation of previous iterations, however there is very little new under the table. Most of the changes that are required for an optimal game play have simply been ignored by the devs.

1. Fixture congestion is a real problem, you will often have f.ex. 11 days with no fixtures or internationals only to have to play 3 games in 6 days, in a WC season I had 6 games in 12 days. It has been problem for a long time.

2. First team players who aren´t constantly starting will be restricted to light training schedules if you have a very busy season with games every 2nd or third day. It means they aren´t really evolving, sending them to the U23 squad to get normal training makes them unhappy and the "elevator" micro management of each player isn´t desirable either. A simple solution for U23 players would be to have the "Available for first team" option but so far I havn´t been lucky in getting any responses.

3. Regardless of tactics you will still encounter "super keepers" who just are your only opponent, their entire team getting 6.2 avg rating while the keeper is getting 8.5, I still win, sometimes by a large margin but their keeper is often MoM still. I have lost 4 finals in a row, conceded 4 goals in 4 shots while their keeper made MoM in all games.

4. Penalties are weird, in one of the 4 above mentioned finals I missed 5 penalties, Wolves missed 4 and scored on the last thus winning. At least the AI is having difficulties with penalties as well, in the league I have about a 50% penalty conversion rate and so does the AI, this has gradually worsened as seasons have passed so it could be a regen issue.

5. Speed/Pace still has too much of an influence.

6. While you can be successful without constant high pressing it´s difficult, it´s doable but tactics rely too much on total pressing. This especially proves true if you have high acc/speed players.

7. The AI harassing you about wanting your players is okay, in FM however this gets taken to entirely new level and you can hear about it every single week throughout an entire season how much X club wants half of your team. When it comes to the bidding however .... they try to buy your players for peanuts. Aston Villa would probably receiving 3-5 bids every week of about 20 million euros in FM in 2037 on a relative comparison, he is worth about 50 million I believe.

8. You get asked the same questions from the press every single week, one would think they would have had the time to develop interviews to be diverse, it´s like a loop that never ends.

9. The training schedules from the ass. manager are horrendous, they may work if you can´t be bothered to change them but results on the pitch definitely improve vastly with a lot of tweaking. This becomes especially true when you are involved in all competitions and the schedule has heavy duty training the day before a match.

A great addition to the Football Manager series, having played every game developed by this team since Championship Manager 93/94, I can say this is the best version yet adding real world complexities into the game for an immersive experience,  The one criticism is it needs more options for interactions with the Players.

I tell myself every time I buy a version of FM that I won't buy the in-game editor. Then I do, find a bunch of young players with excellent potential ability, move them to my team, and start winning heavily. The regret starts to set in. Was my success because of the excellent vertical tiki-taka tactics I've employed? What about the custom set piece routines I've set? Maybe it was the individual training? 

No. It was me loading 15 to 25 of the best youngsters in the database into a bus marked "free candy" and then trapping each of them into a contract that makes indentured servitude seem like a good deal. I've ruined 4 saves this way and am working on ruining my 5th. I know there's a way to disable the editor, but I will never do it.

10/10. Would sabotage my own saves by cheating with the in-game editor. It beats save-scumming.

You know when you're playing a game and you get so into it that you lose all track of time and Space? 
One minute you've sat down at 5pm and the next minute its 3am, you've had 40 cups of tea, you haven't slept in 5 days and you're only half way through trying to scout the perfect striker for your 4-3-3 gene press custom formation. 

For me, this is that game. 

Its grand for all levels of player, you can ease yourself in by trying to win the league with a top tier team and assign all tasks to your assistant, or go full balls to the wall, start off right at the bottom, take on all the assignments yourself, and climb those leagues for ultimate glory.

The in game editor can be fun too, ever wanted to ruin the entire economy of Spain? Or maybe you want to see your rivals fall down the leagues? How about making an entire team of Jeremy Corbins? The world is literally your oyster.

As a ex. FIFA Career Mode player, I have heard great things about this game for years. Finally on December 2020 I decided to buy this game after 14 wonderful years with FIFA and it has been the greatest decision I have made with gaming. 

The amount of freedom you can get with tactics and training is just fascinating. Player/team interactions and team-meetings. I love every aspect in the game currently. The thrill of improving your youth intake and signing for ex. a 16-yo Norwegian Mezzala from Molde to your team. To press conferences ( [i] your sayings can actually matter, not like in FIFA where there is just automaticly generated answers to Q's No consequenses after what you have just said. Just answers and vibes [/i] ).

Eventhough it has been a great improvement on playing football career mode as manager, there could be lots of things to implement into the game. My listings:

- More tactical freedom per player (when leading a crucial game by 1-0 and few minutes remaining as underdog, you could inform your wingers to go near corner flags and hold the ball up there. Tho you have a TEAM instruction to frequently waste time)

- How many touches preferred before pass in which area of the field
- More tactical freedom in formation

FIFA has the gameplay, more licenses BUT FM21 has all the other aspects of non-arcade football that is the closest football game regarding realism. Only reason I would buy FIFA again is that if they decide to release CM game as their own game and made a full team to handle that.

I am doing a pentagon challenge (all 5 champions leagues) to thoroughly test this game. I will edit at the end. So for a very short version, this review is negative, but not as a complete let-down - to me this is a 5/10 game. The philosophy is steering back into the right direction, it can be fun once again and there are certain improvements. But there's so many small things wrong, considering we pay full price for basically a database update and some minor UI improvements every year, there is no excuse.  Also additions to the game are starting to feel like bloat, rather than extras.

Anyway, for the long part - I'm a huge football manager/championship manager fan, I'm one of those old fans who made the game what it is, sinking thousands of hours into it and recommending it left and right. From Bojinov to Yaya Sanogo, I've been along for the ride. At some point the games lost their "fun" for me in exchange for realism and I stopped buying them. 

Starting with the positive, I should say this is the first FM I've actually had fun with since 14. I don't regret 15 and 16 but they were more of a challenge I got through than a game I had fun with. I also tried 20 and hated it. The match engine to me is a huge improvement over 20 and even a huge improvement over old ones where you had to play around certain huge weaknesses, such as very poor striker movement. In this one it feels like you have a choice. Long passes are back and are no longer just a tool for direct, counter-attacking football. Fullbacks actually contribute to the match and aren't a burden. Your tactics, players and decisions are more in control than the code of the game. 

The graphics improvements are also nice. These two things alone show a shift in what should have been the philosophy from the start, focus on graphics and keep the fun. 

HOWEVER, the game is riddled with small bullshit that just kills all the enjoyment when you encounter it. The biggest one for me is that it can get way too easy - set a strategy, get the right players for it, have a bit of depth and watch the game play itself. There's no challenge in getting the right players - if in previous FMs it was ridiculously hard to buy or sell specific players (such as in smaller leagues) in this one its hilariously easy. You can easily form a team to challenge the champion's league with the budget of a second tier italian side (albeit not with that reputation, since players seem almost 100% motivated by reputation on whether they move). Playing in a lower league? Get a 100k $ transfer budget or free up some wage budget and you will easily buy out the entire league. I like the "ask agent for availability" thing, I really do, but since transfers seem so much easier, it just adds even more ease. Spam it on players and you can essentially have an overview of the exact price of every player on the market. 

The second most annoying thing for me has to be the end of every match. Now I felt I was getting scored on/scoring way too much towards the end and I looked at the stats - in a single season I had 60 goals total scored and scored against me. Out of those 60 a staggering 22 were in the last 10 minutes. More than a third!!! An even more staggering 8 of those were AFTER 90 minutes! Nearly 10%. My players were determined, ok with stamina, nothing special and I made no big changes to tactics at the end. I monitored the AI and it rarely did anything either. The second season I played the case was roughly the same. 

Injuries - I feel like the frequency of injuries is ok and players recover realistically. But for some reason small injuries, i.e. a 2-3 day tight groin, a cold or a virus are ridiculously common. This is quite annoying. 

It also feeds into my next point, which is the vast amount of bloat and micromanagement. I've never liked press conferences, but I give them a try every time since I feel its unrealistic to just ignore the press. But these gestures just add more bloat to what felt already like bloat. Same with player interactions - I try, I really do, but by the 6th time your entire team is unhappy you won't sell your only good striker for pennies with no possible replacement and you just have to go through the entire conversation over and over with no real choice, just pressing the same buttons, adding gestures is again, bloat on top of bloat. The UI has been discussed enough, but its the same case for me. I feel these things take away from the core game and create a lot more opportunity for small problems that break the enjoyment.

Some more, minor issues - wingbacks are hilariously overpowered in the right setting, easily scoring a hattrick with long shots outside the box. For that matter, crazy long shots are still here and still way too common, getting a "oooh! magnificent goal!!" from an unlikely player twice a game really ruins the fun of scoring them. Trust me, get a wingback with okish technique and set him to stay wide and shoot - watch as he gets unmarked, never pressured and smashes ridiculous shots over and over. Lastly, when a team finds space it will do so over and over again and trying to close that space by adjusting tactics will rarely work. On the other hand, if you find a weakness in the AI it will basically never cover it - hence if you score 2 in the first half you'll probably score 5-6 by the end. This especially ruins one of the most fun parts of FM, developing youngsters, as a youngster underperforming can easily make you concede a ton of goals on its own. 

Now I could overlook all of this, I really could, but we're getting sold essentially the same game every year. And millions are supporting it. How many developers can boast a 100% guaranteed revenue stream? So with that in mind, to have these small mistakes and oversights is just not acceptable. So many of the reviews to me seem like "well it's football manager and its functional, so five stars", which misses the point. I think reviews should serve to point the game in the right direction and to me that's thorough testing rather than changing the already great UI or adding more options for interactions.

I'm not a sports fan of any team game in our known universe.  As a matter of fact, I've always hated team sports.  These hates have spanned about 65 years.  I tried team sports in school while growing up, I hated them all.  The funniest fact of all is that soccer was my most hated team game next to basketball.  Soccer was THE most hated team sport, the top of my hate list.  Man has hands and soccer won't let him use them.  Stupid.

However...

My most favored genre of games are management, builder, and simulation.  In 2020 I saw Football Manager 2020 and instantly hated it.  The only good looking part of what I saw on Steam was the color purple.  I like purple.  Then I saw the word Demo.  I also like the word Demo, reminds me of the word Free.  Soooooo, I tried the Purple Demo.

Then...

I was amazed at the massive amount of management options, supported with tooltips and help.  The more options I tried, the deeper I fell into management bliss.  One option led to another option, and a spiderweb of fun began to form.  I was liking the sport of soccer, team sport and all!  Pretty soon I owned FM2020, then FM2021, a purple mass of team sport management greatness.  The many varied ways these games inter connect within themselves is beyond amazing.  I've been impressed with a few choice games of this genre, but never even close to the amazement of this FM series by Sports Interactive.

1. Visualization in 3D pitch is horrific. 
2. Whatever formation, mentality, players instructions and strategies doesn't reflect clearly during highlights and keeps you on your toes what is happening when you played attacking while having 0 shots for almost 30 minutes. 
3. Randomly, your players could be playing like Barca and other times possessed by school boys while playing against weaker team. 
4. Whether teams seem motivated or fired up doesn't reflect on match statistics and you will expect there are more prompters/asst manager or coach to do the "observation" for you and give advises or actual situation to react accordingly. 
5. There is also no longer advise to play shorter/direct passes during wet weather or weather events which I thought were vital information. 
6. Not sure why do info such as players lacking tactical familiarity only appears right after team selections and not easily reflected during training.
7. Wingers could run across the entire pitch just to pass to side netting - almost all the time.
8. When your players have negative confidence on the pitch, they will tend to pass to opposition so they can quickly go home and eat popcorn.
9. Playing cautiously against strong teams will make players so nervous, they tend to kick to opposition players all the time even when they are not being pressed and have another 6 teammates within passing distance. 
10. Gegenpress with High intensity and pressing game with hard tackling shows players running or strolling with opposition player with the ball refusing to tackle - all the way from opposition half to 6 yard box, almost all the time. 
11. On one instance, all players stood still while the ball rolled into the net with the keeper 30cm away and the nearest players were near penalty spot. 

I don't see how tactics and strategies really matter when the game engine is so buggy. I don't find it realistic to see players passing to oppositions all the time when morale or confidence is negative or even when leading and complacent.

As a fan of the last two releases, more specifically 20, this game is a welcome edition. From FM20, to FM21, there are a lot of notable changes that make the experience feel incredibly fresh and brand new. The new interface and mechanics make this the best FM game that I've played to date! The inclusion of being able to shout individual orders at individual players makes the "shout" system actually feel useful; (so far) press conferences actually feel like they matter, rather than the filler they have been for ages. 

The updated match engine offers a more slick and smooth feel to the game as it unfolds. Players move a lot more realistic compared to previous titles, which makes goals feel a lot more rewarding for one reason or another. 

The more I play, the more I'll be able to talk about. But after day 1 of the beta? So far; so good!

EDIT: I can confirm the game is STILL very good. If you love your football, buy it.

Football Manager 2021 engulfs you in it's wonderfully complex world that, makes you [i] feel [/i] like you are a manager.

The tactical mechanics are fun to use and work well, but it could be taken to a deeper level. One way of achieving this would be to allow players to adjust formations automatically based on the phase of play, just as teams do in real life. 

For example switching from a 4-3-3 to a 3-4-3 when in possession of the ball, where your CB's split and your DM drops between them, while both FB's move higher up the pitch into a Wing Back position.

I believe console games offer something similar to what I am describing.

FM continues to improve and I am glad to see improvements to the match engine, but I must admit that I do dream of a match engine built by one of the big boys...

Transfers feel realistic, clubs negotiate astutely at times and it's not often I get frustrated when clubs are being unreasonable... but perhaps that's in fact, less realistic?

Overall it's a solid effort with real improvements, some of the highlights being the UI and match engine upgrades. I will however continue to pray the day comes we get to see what a top shelf game engine looks like in a Football Manager game.

IT COSTS 50 EUROS PER YEAR AND IS NOT OPTIMIZED UNTIL MARCH (GOES ON SALE IN NOVEMBER)

Well, after 1 season with Wigan (I was promoted to the Championship, 20 was expected) and 3 seasons with Valencia CF, I have won the Champions League, the League and the National Cup. My forward Maxi Gómez has been the top scorer of the three seasons (a team that in real life struggles to be in the center of the table).

I feel that this game does not convey emotions to me. It is a game without a soul. These are the reasons:

-AI does not pose any challenge to the user. The decisions they make are absurd as I expect great teams to constantly sign players, make efficient tactical changes to fight my team, and hire a coaching staff that lives up to their reputation.

-This leads me to talk about the DIFFICULTY of the game. Year after year I notice how the difficulty decreases. This is bad news for veteran FM players. Simply knowing how to place the players with high morale and in a more or less acceptable position for the player, the job is done. I don't know if this is an SI strategy for attracting customers, what I do know is that it will make long-time loyal customers get tired of spending money every year. My experience sharing FM with people who come from other management games / soccer games is that they consider that the game has too many clicks (well, that's another story, for example I really appreciate the immersion that I am not feeling this year). Simply, that type of user just wants to press a button and have his team score goals. Wrong SI strategy in my opinion.

Another note on difficulty: the game is based on streaks / matches won without losing streaks / matches without winning streaks, the latter being very rare.

-This leads me to talk about the ATTRIBUTES having almost no effect. I have come to use clearly offensive midfielders as a recovering midfielder and they have had disconcertingly positive stats. Something that already happened in previous FM. Experiments are known in which people have used goalkeepers from the U23 team as forwards and have had positive results, scoring goals as real killers.

- Game day experience is terrible. Much information is missing. I can't move my players from the match screen, for example. I have to go through the tactics window for everything. The timeline has disappeared, something I used frequently. I am supposed to have my second coach by my side but I cannot consult him when I want (?). The tips disappear when a play is played and I can't go back to them.

Other aspects with which I am not going to elaborate much:

-Use a 4231 gegenpress, you will win everything and without physical consequences on your players. Take a starting eleven and repeat it, without doing rotations and you will win them all.
-The interface: a lot has already been said about how poorly implemented it is and how little intuitive it is.
-Press conferences: what a useless novelty. It is still repetitive and also now takes me longer, its consequences being very little visible in the game.
-You can't trust your employees at all because their actions are just stupid. (an AI problem that has dragged the game down year after year)

The only positive that would come out of this FM is the improvement of the ME. And although some details have to be polished to give it more realism, I must say that it has been a great improvement compared to last year (something that was not very difficult).

Finally, another thing that makes me very furious is paying for a game that won't really be ready until February or March. Although, sadly, this happens frequently in many new games. This, as consumers, is something we would have to react and act on.

Last year I was one of the clients who said this year's news wouldn't fool me and I still fell in love. That will not happen again.

At the time of this review, I've logged 254.5 hours of playtime. A large volume of that time has involved testing elements including the user interface and match engine, as opposed to playing the game normally. 

After purchasing every version of Football Manager, and its Championship Manager predecessor, FM 21 is the poorest iteration in the series. 

Somewhat controversially, the game is only a meagre update of FM 20 with some additional stats like xG sprinkled on top. While the game’s marketing materials suggest that the new innovations stretch to more complex interactions with the club’s board and squad, those are, at best, trivial and simply add more bloat to the standard user experience. 

With regards to the match engine, there have been the customary patches from the developer to correct a myriad of technical issues. All of which have been detrimental to the immersion of watching two teams play competitive football. However, this year’s offering stands out as recent patches to the game have caused further, more serious issues with the analysis of player performance. At present, there’s an issue where individual player ratings have been greatly reduced across the board. For experienced players of the series, it’s unusual to see players win end-of-season awards with average ratings between 7.1-7.25. 

Callum Wilson scored 35 goals in 35 games in my last season, an incredible haul, and barely scraped an average of 7.1. Full backs, wingers and central midfielders all suffer as the game doesn’t currently track key tackles, an important performance metric for players who aren’t scoring or creating. 

The animations reflected within the match engine have been increased in volume, but the player behaviour has become farcical. Defenders standing still when they can easily reach a ball first is a frequent occurrence and renders so much of the players tactical activity meaningless. The developer’s forum keeps a track of the list of issues which have been fixed and those that are still being worked upon. 

Another disappointing trend has been the number of clicks a user must make to access information which used to be easy to retrieve 5-6 years ago. The implementation of the ‘social’ tab where a large amount of the game’s news is hidden beneath has only grown in size with every new version. 

In the developer’s quest to be seen to bring innovation to the annual release, so much of that innovation is presented as affecting the most laborious aspects of the game. Press conferences. Player interactions. Board interactions. 

All of this leads to the user making more clicks in order to advance to the core managerial gameplay. Meanwhile, not enough innovation has been brought to the manner in which the match engine produces content. 

There’s also a disappointing lack of options for users to rearrange parts of the user interface to best suit their needs. The new match-day experience presents a vast amount of data through an extremely limited number of panels. Few of which are customisable. This creates a bottleneck of data visualisation which is so needless and easy to fix. 

This year, IGN came down hard of FIFA 21 for the Nintendo Switch for charging full price for what was essentially a threadbare update of FIFA 20 on that platform. Other review outlets did the same. Whilst there’s clearly been the challenge of developing during the pandemic, the game is a weak update of FM 20 with more than enough immersion-breaking bugs that the game simply cannot be recommended.

With thousands of hours in FM starting in 2008 I can safely say this is the update I've been waiting for. The last few releases have felt like re-skins but they've made some really nice changes this year.

Firstly the match engine has definitely been improved. I see some comments saying it hasn't but if you've played/watched enough FM games you'll know the outcome of almost every highlight during a game but now some things will happen that you didn't expect. For example teams can counter attack 2 or 3 times before someone actually has a chance. Passing and movement seem much slicker too. The interface now shows useful information in-between highlights such as match stats, player ratings, opposition formation and a live league table instead of just staring at an empty pitch.

Outside of the match engine I've noticed players don't moan as much and are easier to appease. Usually every season half of my squad want to move to a bigger club but in 3 seasons so far I've only had 2 players ask, I convinced both to stay.

At the end of the season there's what I can only describe as a presentation of your season highlights. From a veterans point of view it's a really nice touch. It shows all the things I would usually look for at the end of a season in a really nice format, without me having to check each one manually or through an email. Things like player/manager awards, most goals, most assists, signings of the season, best results, reputation/stature change and a lot of other things I can't remember 😂

They have tweaked some of the menus and when you can do certain things which took a while to get used to. Usually I buy the new FM and autopilot but this year I actually had to learn some stuff which is good.

My only gripe is the lack of skins (not a fan of the purple) but there are so many available for free online that it's not a problem.

Keeping it short:

+best match engine of any FM's ever
+content for years to play and experience (huge database of nations and playable players)
+faster loading and especially much faster saving times

-absolute horrible UI design
-terrible workflow with the current UI
-only 1 UI skin at game launch
-wasted resources (gesture system) on a part of the game most players ignore
-actual matchday UI is like being thrown back into a midst 90's adventure game, in a bad way!

Is it worth it? Yes. BUT,

this years saving grace is the improved match engine and the faster loading/saving. Without it, the rest of the game is actually worse than the couple years before (first and foremost and most importantly the UI design).


Edit after 3 more weeks:

FM21 is riddled with fundamental, underlying bugs. It is even moreso than previous years a frekking blender. The match engine is also not what it looked like at first. There are still fundamental issues at work here too. But most importantly, the "under-the-hood workings of FM21 - like AI player signings, AI player generation, or even simple stuff like moving senior players from main to reserve back to main teams JUST DOES NOT WORK.


Tbh, even the "imporved" match engine doesnt rectify them asking full AAA $$$ for this really really subpar product. 

I just cannot recommend the game anymore under these conditions. THUMBS DOWN.

I have been playing since CM2. I usually watch full game in 2D for a few matches when I set up new tactics. I can say with certainty the match engine in FM17 was more realistic. In FM21 the animations improved, but the match engine took a step backwards. The defenders seem to be rather afraid of the ball. It is very common for an attacker to dribble for 60 meters and arrive in the box without any pressure from defence.

FM17 had more and better 3D cameras. Also the 2D (not the classic) was by far far far better than this awful one in FM21.

I can't say the UI improved. On the other hand I find it worse than FM17.

In scouting, scout for player card only is not an option anymore. Minimum 1 week scouting. Scouting process may be more realistic now, but finding players got more difficult than FM17.

Dynamics and Training are nice additions since FM17. 

Overall it is a less enjoyable game than 17. I knew that when I played the demo before I bought it. However hardcore FM fans need to own it anyway.

FM21 is not a bad game. But, if you have 20, don't waste your money on 21.

Much like VAR irl, realism and accuracy have been shoehorned in over an enjoyable experience:
1) Love hearts and thumbs up for fitness and condition. Why?! Yes, I know real managers don't have exact numbers but it looked so much better and was so much simpler to have %.

2) My biggest gripe. The match day screen. I have no idea what developers were thinking here. There's been a great UX for years imo and I get the need for renovation but the most important information I need; my players performance, their condition, and body language have now been squashed to the bottom of the screen and replaced with inane stats.

3) Team talks. Did the screen really have to change from a list to a 'room'? It's added nothing to the experience and isn't instantly clear if what I've said is motivating or not.

4) Body language. Just a gimmick. I used it once or twice and now ignore it.

If you're a sporadic buyer of FMs then this is a good choice to come back in to. I'm sure loads of people will enjoy the game and it is still fun. It's just not as good as 20, and nowhere near the classics (07, 11, 12, etc)

Football Manager 2021 is the first FM game I have purchased since FM05 and before then CM01/02. The bones of the game haven't changed massively since then even as a lot of bells and whistles have been added. It is still an extremely in-depth football management simulation that still requires a massive time commitment in order to get anywhere. 

My impression is that in comparison to those early 00s versions, the game is trying to provide you with more assistance in figuring out what you actually need to do to have success. That is actually a big plus. In the old games there was a bit of an arcane element which could lead people down the rabbit hole for sure. There's still some of that but there is a more apparent effect of cause and reaction to what you do and how it affects the outcomes. 

There are also mechanisms that clearly were designed to take some off the workload from you. This also seems like a welcome attempt to make the game more accessible, and honestly it's very much needed. All the bells and whistles added since those early 00s games have hugely increased the amount of things on your plate as a manager in FM. If you've ever held a job in which monitoring an email inbox was a big part of your duties, well, much of the game will feel remarkably like that job to you.

I have found that it was relatively easy and still satisfying to go through all that as long as you still feel that drive to lead your beloved club to that promotion, that league title, and eventually that European trophy. Once you've done that though and have gotten your 100 hours in just to accomplish that, well, the tediousness of it all may very well catch up with you. It can easily take a full day of playing this game just to get through an off-season. Even during a pandemic with nothing else going on, and your 'office' being the living room couch, that started to wear on me eventually. 

My feedback is thus still the same it was give or take 15 years ago. This is game that is aimed at hobbyists. And I don't mean people for whom football is the primary hobby, I mean people for whom playing football computer games is the primary hobby. This is a 1000+ hour plus game. The old adage "Less is more" is certainly something SI could take to heart to make a wider audience happier i.e. football lovers who still nevertheless enjoy the company of people, want to pursue other activities etc.

In spite of that, I will give it a recommended vote because if you love football and want to play a football computer game, this is certainly the best option out there right now given the relative decline of the FIFA/PES series. And at least for now, I think most of us have just enough time to at least get some joy out of it.

It does have a lot of glitches. Defenders will run away from attackers running straight at them. Strikers will be through on goal and boot it at the corner flag. Almost no reference to Covid at all which seems strange. They could have done much better.

The best football manager yet.

I was fairly critical last year as they hadn't built on anything from the previous year, was fairly clunky and the match engine left a lot to be desired. You didn't want to keep playing.

This years however is so much better, even the little tweaks. The match engine is superb and it actually makes you keep playing even if you are not invested into a save.

The speed the game plays at now is a huge improvement and the UI is still okay but can be improved (way too many extra clicks). Bugs are almost non-existent which considering most of the development was done at home is pretty amazing.

The main dissapointment is once again regen faces & manager avatars. They are really poor and have not improved from 2012, when SI continues to neglect its superb modding community that make lifelike faces. For example, Laura (Chilled Moose) makes faces that SI could only dream off. Why not hire somebody like her to oversee an overhaul of the regen faces?

FM has a great modding community & they should utilise them more. Let people have more control over skinning and let people play around with their own UI's (that SI could use in future additions).

Oh and still no improvements to online play, FM would take off to another market if it brought back FM Live, such a good game that was way ahead of its time but the stubborn Miles poo-poo's it everytime it is brought up.

Have played FM19 and FM20 and now FM21 which to me has seen a great improvement to the match engine and game speed (I do have a pretty good computer so this might not be the case for everyone)
As always there are the standard licensing issue with club names, logo's and what not but this is easily "fixed" with mods and "how to guids" on the several fan websites to make the experience even more glorious!
You can download face packs, logo packs (for clubs, leagues and cups) real name fixes and additional leagues, for free or for a small fee, it's up to you really how immersive you want to make the game.

Of course the critical gamer would ask "why isn't all this content in the game already"? 
Quite simply put; licensing and plain old money! Football clubs and leagues have gone the big money route and for even to use their name / logo / faces etc you downright have to throw cash at them and if SI (devs) were to use that route this game wouldn't be the price it is at now but about 10x as expensive if not more so just do as all the others do and look for websites that help you create the immersion you want from your Football Manager career!
The game has regular updates (after transfer dates usually) to keep it as accurate to the real world.
The game can seem hard to learn and overwhelming at times when you are new but luckily there are a ton of content creators on Twitch and Youtube explaining the game so you can get up to speed in no time.

This game, with it's in depth management, is for the "hardcore manager" and not for the casual "one season a day" player that wants to quickly manage it's hometown club to glory... you will have to invest time into bringing glory to your club and it won't be easy as a new player but if you have the time and energy to learn this game it will give you great fun, excitement (will the new Messi come through your club's youth system? Will you discover the next Cristiano Ronaldo at some obscure club?).
If you like in-depth management and football then this game is for you!

**Small note** This game can be demanding on your pc (depending on your pc specs and the "database" you load; amount of players and leagues you set to be in the database)
So if you are unsure your PC can run this at a decent pace you might want to try out the demo version first
What a game, so addictive and simply the most realistic football game out there and the gameplay for the matches is much better than fm20.

If you love football and manage a team FM 21 is the game for you. The latest in the series with great support from the community for even greater immersion (skins, kits, backgrounds, banners) is a must have.  Be pre[ared to be entertained for many, many hours. Well worth the $

FM20 was already the most complete sports simulation game ever made, and this is a significant improvement upon it. The reworked match engine looks amazing and resembles the real sport like it never has before. The addition of stats such as xG make team and player evaluation more intuitive and fun, and I hope they add even more advanced stats in the future. Interacting with your players and staff is engaging, and what you choose to say to them will matter. Did you just scout some some obscure player from New Zealand and want to know what awards and milestones they've achieved? No problem. Want to see who won the Belarusian Premier League 8 years ago? Easy. All the minute details such as these that I crave in a sports game are there. 10/10

The game has some fancy and shiny new features and the new match engine seems nice at the first glance but it allows the heavy pressing / attacking approach to be even more efficient than in previous versions, therefore the game lacks balance and there's basically like one tactic that will win you everything while you'll struggle while trying different styles. Also the game is really bugged with small and annoying things (also I'm hearing there are some breaking bugs). Maybe after a couple of patches they'll fix some of the bugs at least (I don't have any hopes for the match engine anymore). As of now this is probably the most disappointing release of FM ever and I've been playing this game since FM05.

Edit: the support team actually suggests to some users to start a new save when they can't fix issues from save games from earlier versions of the game. I SERIOUSLY ADVISE AGAINST BUYING THIS GAME.

Edit no.2: In case some people think that I'm just ranting because I lost a match while having 50 shots vs opponents 1 or sth like that, here's a list of currently unsolved game-breaking issues that are reported by the players:
- Broken youth intake - not playable and view-only leagues do not provide new players. Makes the game unplayable after couple of seasons
- Broken fixtures in Premier League - season 2 in PL you get 2 away games with one random team and 2 home games with another random team. Gets worse every season to the point of complete randomness.
- Broken squad registration 2nd season - teams do not register their players at all and play youth only
- Many more, not game breaking but irritating / killing immersion (like press article half-season about Man City securing survival in the league)

Note - these bugs do not appear 100%, however for anyone who wants to buy this game, if you start a new save you're risking running into those issues.

UI is worse than ever! Remember that panel on the match screen that the ass man spams with useless feedback that everyone swapped out? That's now nailed on to your match screen and you can't get rid of it and it's even spammier! Likewise they nailed on a match stats panel, but removed the ability to customize what stats are displayed, so if you want any other stats you have to use one of the remaining panel slots to add ANOTHER match stats panel... what kind of dingleberry came up with this shit?!

But the UI fuckery isn't limited to the match screen. They've turned the player condition into some bullshit smartphone icon nonsense. So now you have no clue if your player is at 100% and able to play the entire match or 90% and about to be gassed by half-time... shocking stuff!

Match engine is much prettier this year, but under the hood it's the same dumpster fire. Low blocks still somehow get beaten by over the top long balls, it's still gegenpress or gtfo, defenders will still opt to mark their man instead of closing down the guy advancing towards goal unopposed, if you want wingers you still need to use wingbacks because actual wingers straight up refuse to play any different than IWs/IFs and all of them continue to shoot from 5 degree angles instead for passing. 


Tactical options are still limited as ever, setting up training is still clunky AF, there's still no individual training focus for some attributes (like tackling wtf), game is still littered with gimmicks that just waste your time without serving a purpose (who needs var when the ai has already made the calculation?! Also, moving the text around doesn't make pressers any less crap)... Oh and transfers get ridiculous real quick... prepare yourselves for Neymar at Gladbach

If you've ever played Football Manager before, and maybe you've been turned off by the lack of features added in previous additions, FM21 is for you. This addition adds a brand new match engine, advanced stats like xG, so many analysis charts and graphs that previously weren't included in the base game, and new player talks and transfer meetings. I have played FM for the past couple of years (since around FM17) and this is EASILY the best Football Manager I have ever played. I have to give credit to sports interactive, because they really did step up this year. Improvements and adjustments could be made of course, but I have very little complaints this year. This game is by far the most in depth and advanced sports game out there if you love stats and managing your own team, and I would recommend this to any football fan at 50$, and even to non-football fans.

I don't want to give this game a negative review but I will until the following issues are fixed. Mainly because SI stated they were going to fix it but still have not, making the game incredibly difficult for me to play for extended periods. 

Some UI decisions have been questionable at best. They didn't even take into account those with poor vision or colourblindness, like myself. 

It's so hard for me to gauge my players fitness. They say "it was unrealistic to see a players fitness by a percentage". Well it's also unrealistic to know a players exact "reaction" after a shout. When I hear a manager shouting in real life on the side line - I don't see them take out a smiling emoji?!?!?! Nor do they smile, give a thumbs up or act delighted. 99% of footballers are so focused they totally ignore anything and the only reactions you do see are celebrations or anger fuelled by their adrenaline. So lets put this talk of "realism" on the back burner and put our eyesight and long term/extended play as a priority. If it aint broke, don't fix it.

Also regarding fitness etc. At least you hear managers say in real life "he's about 70% fit at the moment". Knowing a players "feelings" by body language is way more unrealistic - same as morale.

Some other UI decisions are weird - like the crooked "official team sheet" that represents data on an angle - totally triggering my OCD. Never present data on a weird angle - its ugly. 

Also when you do team talks - theres half the starting line up on the left and then the attackers along the top. Si stated and I quote "this is a bug we will be looking to fix for the full release". Still not fixed. Also highly triggers my OCD and it's just difficult to look at. This was perfectly fine on FM2020...just leave this stuff alone, seriously.

The match engine is a huge improvement but I still see a lot of "ping pong" rebounds and very odd decisions where players keep trying to all shoot into a wall of players. I almost felt compelled to make a video of it with pinball sounds as a joke. I also noticed that there is some match speed changes this year. Match speed at 50% feels like its in slow motion at times and 1 notch to the right seems too fast.

Match sounds (which have not been updated in over 15 years) have managed to regress again. It suddenly and abruptly cuts off during highlights - giving the game an unpolished feel. I know 99% of FM players play with the sound off but sound is a huge part of football - it's a huge part of the atmosphere. Covid has already taken this away from us in 2020, so please fix the sounds or work on a HUGE expansion to the sound in FM22!!! The only reason 99% of players play with the sound off is because its bad. They don't play with the sound off because they want to. If FM21 had similar sounds to say (FIFA or PES) they wouldn't play with the sounds off. This is the classic chicken or the egg question...you tell me this. How many people play FIFA or PES with the sound off. How many people play ANY game with the sound off?? That's right - not many - if any. Improve your sounds and you will see most people will play with the sound on. 

Selling players is incredibly difficult this year because they tried to add "covid" effects for realism. Look - either add Covid in FULLY into the game with empty stands, the actual virus and all of its effects in the game or leave this cruddy disease out of the game and allow us to forget about 2020 and enjoy a fantasy 2021. I think it should have been totally left out - with 0 effects from covid and allow us to enjoy the game normally, with normal finances and the ability to sell players at least for their value. It does make buying players easier, but then again - most clubs I have managed have a 0 budget to begin with...cause of covid! Thanks!! Can't even enjoy a fantasy.

Also match day camera angles. They now added a zoom to the TV view. This actually gives me a little bit of motion sickness and dizziness at times. I don't experience this with a real life game, but in a video game at 60fps it does make me feel a bit queasy. Please give us an option to turn this off or add more camera angles (like a manager first person view). This is the first FM where none of the camera angles are suitable for my enjoyment. Director Cam is actually fine, but I hate all the other weird and distant angles during corners and throw-ins. Again a director camera with a toggable "other views" would be good.

The other stuff is pretty good - its a big improvement compared to older FM's but some of these design and UI ideas and implementation doesn't take into account those with colourblindness and/or poor vision - causing eye strain during extended play.

As stated, the match engine has improved but its still a bit silly at times.

SI do the same thing year after year - they put in 110% effort and deliver a product to 90%. That extra 10% is always missing and eithe requires multiple patches until March to get things to maybe 95% or they let things slide for another year - then eventually letting things slide for over a decade (like sounds). They need a decent competitor to shoot a rocket up their butts to actually deliver 110% effort and a 110% product. For a full AAA price year after year - and one of the best sellers on STEAM - the old excuse of "we are just a small company" no longer suffices. This is a company that makes hundreds of millions of dollars and hiring some sound developers and giving the game a much larger improvement to atmosphere and graphics shouldn't be as slow as a progression as it has been. Ultimately this game still has graphics of a game from 2006 and sound from a game in the mid 90's. 

Again, this is a game that I love and pump a bunch of hours into - but at the same time - I expect more and I expect a polished product that takes into account people with vision issues, colourblindness, ocd and such.

I will update this to a positive review when they at least fix the UI as they promised. I won't hold my breath for the match sounds to be fixed but I hope that it will be a feature of FM22 "New and improved match day experience and atmosphere!".

My guess is that by FM2030, they still won't have updated sounds.

Here it is, another QoL update for Football Manager 2005. And there is nothing wrong with that (except the full game price we need to pay every year). Sports Interactive continuously evolving the game, making it more detailed. Though their vision about what is needed to be done may differ from yours (so, no multi-monitor support, no female leagues, no from-scratch/sandbox environments), it's hard to deny the effort.
This year they focused on interactions, adding the gestures instead of the old speaking tone. While "kick the chair" may look funny, I doubt I'll ever kick it. But for some people who want to roleplay Jurgen Klopp, it may be of some use.
I'm happier about match interface changes, especially about the detailed "Match Stats" widget. It's finally possible to see woodwork stats again after all those years! (And yes, it's pretty much high).
I can't say much about how useful the recruiting meetings are, as in the first season I usually play with what I have, but they look nice. The same goes for the season review as I still haven't finished one (but can't wait for it).
One of the most important things: they finally fixed visual tearing plagued FM20 on some systems (ignoring VSync settings).
As for the match engine, nothing changed. I loaded my tactics from a previous FM, and it worked without any difference - more or less same stats, same performance, same (expected) results. That's rather good than not. But there is still no different attack and defense formation settings. Even PES has it for years. You can't recreate asymmetrical formation change in FM at the moment, and it makes Andrea Pirlo sad. Maybe next year? Time to give us more tactical flexibility.
Let's cut it short. If you want a quality football simulator, not sports anime/manga-style (PES) and not arcade-style (FIFA), with a huge up-to-date database without errors even in the top team rosters (cough, cough, KONAMI), look no further.

Ugh. I really had high hopes for this one, but unfortunately I was disappointed yet again. 
Besides all the bugs, especially the infuriating visual ones that make some menus and screens literally unusable, the main issue is that defenders are just absolutely horrific. And before the "sdhafhehhfsh it's just your tactics broooo sdhshdfh" crowd comes along, I actually think it's just as big, if not more of a problem on the opposition teams. It's just not at all satisfying to score a goal after the opposition defender, under absolutely no pressure and with multiple passing options in different directions, just decides to run away from the ball and gift it your striker for no reason at all. It would be one thing if this happened occasionally (mistakes happen, obviously), but EVERY SINGLE GAME there are one or more mistakes that would end up on a end of season, maybe even end of decade highlights reel for terrible defending (almost all individual mistakes).
SI's seem to suffer from a complete inability to simulate real football matches, which leads to them forcing totally unrealistic goals so that SOMETHING actually happens (beside the occasional 30 yard screamer). So disappointing!

Another year, another bad review... I know it sound crazy that someone spends 50€ every year and every year is getting disappointed, I know I promised I won't trust SI anymore, but I failed. I saw lots of positive feedback talking about a revolutionary ME and I fall for it.
Of course there is nothing true in those reviews apart from the very smart SI move: make the BETA really easy so that people will start winning every match and leave a positive review. ME is the same as the previous year, the game has the same flaws and I see not a single reason to buy the 2021 if you have 2020 (or 2019, or 2018...).
It is pretty clear to me that FM, as a football manager simulator, died many years ago and now SI has focused on producing movies disguised as videogames. FM2021 is a just the usual mess: 1000 useless buttons, millions of fake details, informations and options. You can click buttons, move sliders, imagine to decide something, but in the end all you really do is to watch the movie that SI has prepared for you.
This year I guess they fired their english screenwriter and went for an Hollywood one because every seems to be pushed to the extreme. Every match is a wonderfull emotional roller coaster with amazing comebacks, crazy overturns and last minute goals, no matter what you try to do.
But it's not just the ME: economy in this game is a joke. You have more options to interact with players, other managers and agents than in SIMS4, you can define extremely complicated contract with options that only someone with a PHD in economy can understand and in the end your player (and all the team after him) gets mad because you don't sell him for 10% of his market value. But who cares about economy in a manager simulator when you have the in-game editor and you can easly make your favourite team richer than Soros?

The conclusion is that the new FM2021 is an incredibly precise simulation of the whole football world. SI has worked very hard once again to try to include and reproduce every aspect around football and I am really impressed by the level of details and similarity to real life they have reached. The only one problem is they forgot they are producing a videogame.
Best FM in their history. It does have a problem with CLOUD SAVES THOUGH! I split my time between work and home and cloud saves was working fine until the last week. Very annoying!

Another year another FM, every year i say i'll skip this one and every year i cave. The reviews all looked great so i took the plunge and honestly this release is so hard to recommend right now. 

The game itself is solid as per,  but the UI is a bit of a mess and really frustrating. Phantom clicks/drag and drops when trying to select the team, end up swapping my striker for a keeper or drilling into the players page. Formation weakness doesn't seem to update straight away or will just highlight different squares red for a couple of seconds before reverting back to normal. Issues with specific player instructions for example you can have Advanced Playmaker role set but when you drill into this to set specifics nothing appears to be selected, 

Never know if the changes i've made on the "touchline tablet" will carry forward to the next game, sometimes they do sometimes they don't. Colour coding makes no sense a journalist can have an negative opinion of me that appears in green then another one will be positive but appear red, i've seen the same thing with player opinions. On one of my first matches i was playing in my away kit, i made a substitution and the player came on in the home kit, i made another and all i could see was a players shadow and their hair,

I've already had two or three crashes, the game seems to think it's graphics related and keeps asking me to check driver, i'm using a 1080 and it's on the latest nvidia driver... could FM21 be the new Crysis?

I'm sure most of this will get patched soon but i'd avoid the game for now if you were on the fence, give it a another month, just like SI should have done for the release date...
