I've only started playing FM since 2019, I know I haven't played a lot of the games but I can say with total confidence that FM21 is one of the best FM games. 

The good:

The game shows improvement in the area of UI, mainly when playing matches where you can comfortably see the status of every player, everything else is pretty much unchanged but that's not a bad thing. 

The match engine has definitely changed. I don't know how to explain it but it feels very smooth and looks (most of the time) like an actual football game. 

The interview mechanic has been overhauled, it now has an actual purpose, it's not like previous games where I didn't care about it at all and skipped them, now you can have relationships with the press and change the mood of players but it can get old pretty fast since the interviewers almost always ask the same questions and at that point, you know what to answer to improve or worsen your relationships.

The bad:

The game is STUPIDLY EASY. I don't know if it's the formation I use or my tactics but it's VERY EASY. I can't emphasize that enough. I've only lost 4 games across an entire season and now I'm almost halfway through my second season and I haven't lost yet. Mind you, I picked an Argentinian football team so it's not like I've chosen incredibly popular teams. 

Sometimes the players do whatever the hell they want. Like I said at the beginning, I don't have a lot of experience when it comes to FM games but players just ignore orders, do whatever the hell they want and make stupid decisions. I'd like to believe that this is some kind of "realism" where players tend to do things wrong and not because of the game itself.

It's also very annoying that at one point, your players will want a raise that reflects their improvement as a footballer but your club will not have enough money to pay them, leading to selling said players. I believe there should be some kind of option or a solution of some sort to tell them: "bro, why you asking so much, we don't have that much money". I've lost 3 good players because of this and even though I managed to mitigate this quite a bit, I'm about to lose a couple more. 

Overall, I think this is a great entry to the FM series, despite the issues, I think the good things outweigh the bad things. If you're thinking of giving the games a try, check this one out. As long as you get past those incredibly frustrating moments, it's a pretty chill game where you can dump time into.

Compared to FM19, this game is a good improvement in my opinion. I haven't played FM20, so I can't compare this game to the last one. 

The match engine feels smoother and better. Players seem to really play football now and it's harder to tell when you will score or concede a goal. There's a also good amount of VAR moments, but it's not an annoying amount as it was in earlier games. 

The interface looks cleaner and feels a lot smoother. Loading times are also better and I really love the new UI. The only issue I have is the new logos that are used for fitness, etc. I hate the hearts and would love if they brought back the option to turn it into numeric percentages. 

The youth development and scouting tabs of the game have been changed and definitely improved. While it seems more advanced, it's also more user friendly to understand what the game is telling you about different players. 

A downside of this game seems to be the punishment you get from playing high intensity strategies, because it seems to really hurt your players and get you a lot of injuries. It somewhat forces you to play a less intense strategy, which doesn't really fit into everyone's playstyle..

The last issue I currently have is the amount of spelling and grammatical mistakes that are in the Dutch translation of this game. I can't tell if this issue applies to other languages as well, but it's annoying. It could and should've been avoided. 

That said, I do think this game is worth it and is a great experience and upgrade from the earlier games. 

8.5/10

This game is such an improvement over the previous editions of football manager that I've played. The match engine has been made so much better, and that seems to be the thing that gets the most attention, and perhaps rightfully so, but I've noticed other smaller things that I'd like to mention. The game seems to run so much smoother than in previous years, so there must have been some overhaul there, and I'm also a very big fan of all the new interactions that you can have. Team talks feel more like team talks than just clicking the same prompt over and over again, and the same goes for press conferences and player interactions. Pre-match briefings are the best they've ever been, and the player feedback you get after setting your tactics also improves immersion. Even little things like the end of season roundup you get has been improved over what it was in previous years; just some emails that pop up in your inbox.  

I could not recommend this game enough, especially for players who are familiar with previous editions but grew disillusioned with the lack of a more realistic match engine or the lack of little quality of life changes. 

I have noticed some bugs here and there, none remotely gamebreaking, but it is still early days in terms of the release, and I can only assume that most of them will be patched in the near future.

Always played on mobile for maybe 7 years now and always wanted to finally get into the PC version. It seems complex at first but there are many people on YouTube with tutorial and of course managing with a top club will give you a better way to get your feet wet while learning the finer details and how to be good at the game. Highly recommended.

Slickest version of FM yet. Made the jump from FM19 to this and it has been worth it. The difference in interactions with players, press, recruitment etc is fantastic and adds a level of immersion that was missing from previous versions. When it comes to squad selection, the extra playing time options is great, for example being able to designate a goalkeeper as a purely cup keeper. Which i find extremely useful as it stops me worrying about whether the virtual player is happy with his playing time.

The revamped match day experience is also very neat and just adds a splash of glamour to everything. Which isn't something i thought i wanted until i experienced it! The match engine looks so good that i've been converted from 2D to 3D, which as a diehard 2D man i didn't think would ever happen!

The new interface does take some great use too, but i imagine that's down to me coming from playing fm19 and missing out the 2020 version.

In summary, if you love football manager, you'll love this game. The jump from fm19 is big enough to make the game value for money. Can't comment on the difference to fm20 however. Great stuff!

FM2021, is not a new game, not remotely new. It's almost identical to the previous versions, but polished up a little. You can shake hands or put your arm around players now; odd that a game about the immersion of being a manager, should not think to add these touches in, a long time ago. I still feel the dialogue between manager and player is too thin, repetitive and vague. But at least now, you can kind of develop a relationship with those players you like and those you don't. But, the makers of FM know that they don't have to produce a new game, because most people only buy it for the updated team sheets. Nobody likes playing, if a player is not adequately skilled because he's developed massively in 9 months, or  player starts off at the wrong club or a youngster just isn't in the game. We buy the game, simply to see Rashford, Mount, Grealish have appropriately high skill ratings, or for Balotelli to be finally rated as poorly as he is in real life, or for Gareth Bale at Tottenham and not at Madrid. The in-game edit function is useful, but not even a dedicated geek is going to make sure Southend United have the appropriate players in their youth team. If you've got £40 to spend, if you liked FM20, then you'll like FM2021, because they are fundamentally the same game.

I've been playing FM since the start in 2005 and have always loved it. I am however disappointed with this year's release. The main problem is during the match where all options for how you want it to arrange your information have been taken away. What you are left with is an information screen popping up in between the highlights with preset information on it, most of which you don't want. It all feels too prescribed and If you want information during a highlight it totally obscures the action. In the last few editions you could choose your layout during matches so that all your data was at hand and you could manage the team on the go. Now you have to stop the match to see whats going on or the next highlight will whip your information away and you've missed the chance to affect the game. Why take away one of the best options in the game?

Having played almost every game of this series since FM07, this one is a mixed bag. I have also been one of those who complained about having to buy a full game for just a design/cosmetic changes to the game. Now having played this for close to 10 odd hours, I am left with a mixed feeling.
This game surely has some nice upgrades, are they worth buying immediately at a full price, is the question?

Positives:
1. Match engine has improved a fair bit. Seems a lot smoother too.
2. New interactions is a step in a positive direction. Must focus on not making it very mechanical for long term users.
3. Transfer fees seem to be toned down a bit. Haven't yet seen an offer of 100+ Millions.

Negatives:
1. Salaries are screwed up. Players in south american/african leagues with below 10k, no international experience are expecting more than 100k. This is way too common an occurence.
2. Why did the devs touch the inbox and themes? This high contrast purple theme is a nightmare. I can barely look at inbox. Why not include dark theme? Why not change it as per team colors like in past? Do not touch what works well.
3. Match engine is better however the quick interaction cards are still unpolished. Randomly these cards become unclickable and only way out is to let time pass a bit, defeating the point of quick interactions.
4. Individual talk annoyed the hell out of me to the point I considered asking for refund. Why would you ask users to manually unselect 10+ players for every individual interaction? Which part of individual did devs not understand?
5. Not sure if its just me, however percentage of shots getting blocked (or bouncing off players) seems unnatural. Follow throughs are getting blocked off, which just seems like unrealistic reflexes, far too often.
6. Even the players with best attributes don't make a run for a ball. Players randomly slow down or hold up and lose possession, and a counter attack starts, is horrific. This has been there in previous versions too.
7. In terms of search, there was a filter which could identify key attributes for a role. This doesn't exist anymore making it much harder to search for staff or players.

Verdict :
Overall the game has some nice changes. Even though mostly cosmetic it may still seem like a fresh change.
If you've never bought a game or haven't bought in last 3-4 years - Definitely purchase this.
If you've been a loyal follower - Wait for it to be on discount.

However overall a positive change.

Football manager 2021 is much improved iteration of FM series. After 60+ hrs of playing time, this is my view on the game,

PROS:

1) Great and modernised Visual Style, it will look good not only in PC but specifically in tabs or smaller laptops

2) Up to date and accurate data base even for obscured leagues

3) Great Game Performance, even for a low to mid end Gaming PC. Saving Time is slashed.

4) Graphically improved match engine. Player interactions are more realistic now

5) Gameplay simulation and Financial simulation is good and realistic

6) Addition of new player and press interaction is great 

CONS:

Some systems specially much hyped xG is not properly explained and cannot ascertain how can it help aspiring managers

Football Manager 2021 is a polished version of the 2020 edition. The game plays smoother than before and the match engine reacts more to your tactical changes and shouts. I can't help myself, but I keep on buying the game each and every single year. 

This years release has no major changes, so if that's what you're looking for: stick to FM20. If the bug fixes, database update and smoother match engine are what you're looking for: do not doubt it and buy this game.
really addictive and it is my first time playing this on pc but overall it is really good and challenging.

Have played the game for years, normally skip out a year between editions to ensure there are significant improvements. Didn't this year as i also had fm20, but dont regret it!

Lots of helpful changes like the transfer meetings, less pre match team meetings these occur just before the game and are more concise, ask agent about availability is a great feature and better match ai 

The cosmetic changes are great too, really like the new match day layout and press conference etc.
a decent upgrade from the 2020 version. The visuals are moderately improved, more dialogue options conveying a sense of realism. other than improved match engine nothing new. would still recommend

Best ME upgrade of the last years. New features are nothing new, but the ME itself is worth buying the game.
11/10 will spend way over 1000 hours playing FM again
